revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1781 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Archery]]== '''Events''' * Foundation of the Toxophilite Society at [[Leicester Square]], London; it later gained royal patronage and became the Royal Toxophilite Society in 1787.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * Unknown.
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The [[Hambledon Club]] abandoned its traditional home at [[Broadhalfpenny Down]] after the members decided it was "too remote" and relocated to [[Windmill Down]] just outside Hambledon village '''England''' * Most runs<ref name="cards">Note that scorecards created in the 18th century are not necessarily accurate or complete; therefore any summary of runs, wickets or catches can only represent the '''known''' totals and the missing data prevents effective computation of averages</ref> – [[James Aylward (cricketer)|James Aylward]] 319 * Most wickets<ref name="cards"/> – [[Lamborn (Hambledon cricketer)|Lamborn]] 27
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1781 Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Young Eclipse]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Faith * [[St Leger Stakes]] – Serina
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year|1781]] [[Category:1781 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1823 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 20 May — [[Tom Spring]] is finally able to defend his English Championship title when he receives a challenge from Bill Neat. The two meet on Hinckley Downs and the fight ends in the eighth round when Neat is forced to retire, having sustained a broken arm in the sixth round.<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/spring-t.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Spring]</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The size of the [[wicket]] is increased to 27 x 8 inches. '''England''' * Most runs<ref name="cards">Note that scorecards created in the first quarter of the 19th century are not necessarily accurate or complete; therefore any summary of runs, wickets or catches can only represent the '''known''' totals and the missing data prevents effective computation of averages</ref> – [[William Ward (cricketer, born 1787)|William Ward]] 328 (HS 120) * Most wickets<ref name="cards"/> – [[William Ashby (cricketer)|William Ashby]] 23 (BB 6–?)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * The traditional date of the [[William Webb Ellis]] legend. He is the [[Rugby School]] pupil who, it is said, "with a fine disregard for the rules of football, took the ball in his hands and ran with it". Even if the tale is true, the game will have been a version of folk football with rules that had been verbally agreed by the Rugby School pupils. Such rules are always open to challenge and it may be that an incident like this did occur with the result that a "dribbling" game became primarily a handling game.
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Zinc (horse)|Zinc]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Nicolo * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Emilius]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Zinc (horse)|Zinc]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Barefoot (horse)|Barefoot]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year|1823]] [[Category:1823 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1849 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 7 February — following years of inactivity, American champion [[Tom Hyer]] finally returns to the ring and fights [[Yankee Sullivan]] at Stillpond Creek in Maryland. Hyer wins in the 16th round. The fight should have taken place at Rock Point, Maryland, on 10 January but the police forced its cancellation.<ref name="TH">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/hyer-t.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Hyer]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref> * [[William Thompson (boxer)|William Thompson]] retains the Championships of England but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1849.<ref name="WT">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/thompson.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Bendigo]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 23, 24 & 25 July — a match between [[Sheffield Cricket Club|Sheffield]] and [[Manchester Cricket Club|Manchester]] at [[Hyde Park Ground]], [[Sheffield]] is styled "Yorkshire v Lancashire" and is therefore both the first match to involve a Lancashire county team and the inaugural ''[[Roses Match]]''. Yorkshire win by 5 wickets. '''England''' * Most runs – [[George Parr (cricketer)|George Parr]] 529 @ 31.11 (HS 86*) * Most wickets – [[William Hillyer]] 141 @ 13.20 (BB 8–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1849 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Peter Simple (racehorse)|Peter Simple]] * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – The Flea * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Nunnykirk * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[The Flying Dutchman (horse)|The Flying Dutchman]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Lady Evelyn * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[The Flying Dutchman (horse)|The Flying Dutchman]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 29 April — the [[The Boat Race 1849 (March)|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]], last contested in 1846, is revived and this 9th race is won by [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] * 15 December — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] is awarded the 10th [[The Boat Race 1849 (December)|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] following the disqualification of [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]]. This is the first and last time that the race is contested twice in the same year.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1849 in sports| ]]

{{Infobox football tournament season | title = 1998 Federation Cup qualification | dates = 18 July–23 August 1998 | other_titles = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | country = [[India]] | num_teams = 37 | champions = | runner-up = | matches = | goals = | prevseason = | nextseason = }} The '''1998 Indian Federation Cup qualification''' tournament was a [[Association football|football]] competition that was played among 37 teams to determine eight teams that entered the [[1998 Indian Federation Cup|final round]]. These teams joined eight other teams that automatically qualified by virtue of entering the quarter-finals in the [[1997 Indian Federation Cup|last edition]].{{cite web|last1=Ghosh|first1=Arnab|title=Mohun Bagan retails title|url=http://www.indianfootball.de/article/article006.html|publisher=indianfootball.de|work=[[Sportstar]]|accessdate=6 February 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020612231945/http://www.indianfootball.de/article/article006.html|archivedate=12 June 2002|date=9 October 1998}} The qualification matches were played separately in five zones and the winner of each zone qualified automatically; with two from the South Zone. The runners-up of other four Zones competed in [[playoffs]] to earn the remaining two spots.{{cite web|title=NZ Federation Cup begins today|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/1998/98aug02/sports.htm#7|work=The Tribune|accessdate=6 February 2017|date=1 August 1998}} The first qualification match, played on 18 July 1998, was an East Zone match and Jorba Durga from the zone became the first team to qualify. The competition ended 23 August with playoffs when Punjab State Electricity Board eliminated Air India and became the final qualifier. ==Qualified teams== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: left;" |- ! |attendance= |referee= }} ===North Zone=== {{Main article|1998 Indian Federation Cup qualification (North Zone)}} The qualification process began with nine teams competing for one or two spots. [[JCT FC|JCT Mills]] qualified for the final round and Punjab State Electricity Board qualified to play the runners-up of other zones to qualify for the final.{{cite web|last1=Gupta|first1=Vikrant|title=JCT make Fed Cup main draw|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/Storyold/46267/|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=6 February 2017|date=11 August 1998}} ==Playoffs== There were two scheduled playoffs to determine the final two qualification spots to the finals. They were played on 20 and 23 August 1997. {{Football box |date=20 August |time= |team1=Bloodmouth, Agartala |score=0–1 |report= |team2=[[Tollygunge Agragami F.C.|Tollygunge Agragami]] |goals1= |goals2= |stadium=[[Agartala]] |attendance= |referee= }} {{Football box |date=23 August |time= |team1=Air India |score=1–2 |report=[http://www.tribuneindia.com/1998/98aug24/sports.htm#2 Report] |team2=Punjab State Electricity Board |goals1= |goals2=Sandip Saini {{goal|3}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Abbasyn Stadium | nickname = ملعب العباسيين | image = Abbasiyyin stadium from a distance.jpg | caption = The Abbasiyyin Stadium from a distance | fullname = | location = [[Damascus]], [[Syria]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|31|22.04|N|36|19|12.58|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1957 | opened = | renovated = 1976, 1992, 2011 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Government of Syria]] | operator = General Sports Federation of Syria | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Syria national football team]]
[[Al-Wahda SC Damascus]]
[[Al-Jaish SC Damascus]]
[[Al-Majd Damascus]] | seating_capacity = 30,000[http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/syr/abbasiyyin_stadium The Abbasiyyin Stadium on stadiumb.com] | dimensions = 105 x 70 m | scoreboard = yes }} The '''Abbasiyyin Stadium''' ({{lang-ar|ملعب العباسيين}}) is a multi-use all-seater stadium in [[Damascus]], [[Syria]], currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches and serves as the home venue of the [[Syria national football team|Syrian national team]]. It is also home to [[Syrian Premier League]] clubs [[Al-Wahda SC Damascus|Al-Wahda]], [[Al-Jaish SC Damascus|Al-Jaish]] and [[Al-Majd Damascus|Al-Majd]]. The stadium which was built in 1976 is able to hold up to 30,000 spectators, being the 4th largest stadium in Syria. ==History== The stadium was originally opened in 1957 with a capacity of 10,000 spectators, to host football matches and local [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] events. On the occasion of the 5th [[Pan Arab Games]] in [[1976 Pan Arab Games|1976]],[http://www.esyria.sy/edamascus/index.php?p=stories&category=places&filename=201002051035011 eDamascus: Abbasiyyin Stadium] the stadium was entirely renovated and the capacity was expanded up to 40,000 spectators. However, after the most recent renovation in March 2011, Abbasiyyin Stadium was turned into an all-seater stadium and the capacity was reduced to 30,000 seats.{{cite web|url=http://www.albaath.news.sy/user/?id%3D1083%26a%3D95953 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315185238/http://www.albaath.news.sy/user/?id=1083&a=95953 |archivedate=2011-03-15 |df= }} Al-Baath newspaper 10 March 2011 Abbasiyyin Stadium hosted the 5th and 7th [[Pan Arab Games]] in 1976 and [[1992 Pan Arab Games|1992]] respectively as a main venue. On 6 May 2001, a holy mass was conducted by [[Pope John Paul II]] in the Abbasiyyin Stadium.[http://www.albayan.ae/one-world/2001-05-07-1.1159710 Pope John Paul II, holy mass in Damascus Abbasiyyin Stadium] ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = [[West Asian Football Federation Championship]]
Final Venue | before = [[Amman International Stadium]]
{{Flagicon|Jordan}} [[Amman]] | after = [[Azadi Stadium]]
{{Flagicon|Iran}} [[Tehran]] | years = [[2002 West Asian Football Federation Championship|2002]] }} {{s-end}} {{Damascus}} [[Category:Football venues in Syria]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Damascus]] [[Category:National stadiums|Syria]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1957]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Syria]] {{syria-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Athletic pubalgia | synonyms = | image = | caption = | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Athletic pubalgia''', also called '''sports hernia''',<ref name=meyers2007> {{cite journal|last1=Meyers | first1=William C.|last2=Yoo | first2=Edward|last3=Devon | first3=Octavia N.|last4=Jain | first4=Nikhil|last5=Horner | first5=Marcia|last6=Lauencin | first6=Cato|last7=Zoga | first7=Adam|title=Understanding "Sports Hernia" (Athletic Pubalgia): The Anatomic and Pathophysiologic Basis for Abdominal and Groin Pain in Athletes|journal=Operative Techniques in Sports Medicine|volume=15 | issue=4 | date=October 2007 | pages=165–177 | issn=1060-1872 | doi=10.1053/j.otsm.2007.09.001 |url=http://jdc.jefferson.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1004&context=radiologyfp}}<!--| accessdate=2012-12-25--></ref> '''hockey hernia''',<ref name="pmid18794316">{{cite journal |vauthors=Omar IM, Zoga AC, Kavanagh EC |title=Athletic pubalgia and "sports hernia": optimal MR imaging technique and findings |journal=Radiographics |volume=28 |issue=5 |pages=1415–38 |year=2008 |pmid=18794316 |doi=10.1148/rg.285075217 |url=http://radiographics.rsnajnls.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18794316|display-authors=etal}}</ref> '''hockey groin''',<ref name=meyers2007 /> '''Gilmore's Groin''',<ref name=meyers2007 /> or '''groin disruption'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.108harleystreet.co.uk//Downloads/AboutGilmoresGroinTheOperation.pdf |title=Gimore's Groin, Symptoms, Diagnosis, Treatment |work=thegilmoregroinandherniaclinic.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=April 30, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203012619/http://www.108harleystreet.co.uk//Downloads/AboutGilmoresGroinTheOperation.pdf |archive-date=2013-12-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> is a medical condition of the [[Pubic symphysis|pubic joint]] affecting athletes.<ref name=pubalgia>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ahumada LA, Ashruf S, Espinosa-de-los-Monteros A, Long JN, de la Torre JI, Garth WP, Vasconez LO | year = 2005 | title = Athletic pubalgia: definition and surgical treatment | url = | journal = Ann Plast Surg | volume = 55 | issue = 4| pages = 393–6 | pmid = 16186706 | doi=10.1097/01.sap.0000181344.22386.fa}}</ref>
It is a syndrome characterized by chronic [[Inguinodynia|groin pain]] in athletes and a dilated [[Superficial inguinal ring|superficial ring]] of the [[inguinal canal]]. [[Football]] and [[ice hockey]] players are affected most frequently, and both recreational and professional athletes may be affected.
==Presentation== Symptoms include pain during sports movements, particularly hip extension, and twisting and turning. This pain usually radiates to the [[Adductor muscles of the hip|adductor]] muscle region and even the testicles, although it is often difficult for the patient to pin-point the exact location.
Following sporting activity the person with athletic pubalgia will be stiff and sore. The day after a match, getting out of bed or a car will be difficult. Any exertion that increases intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or sporting activity can cause pain. In the early stages, the person may be able to continue playing their sport, but the problem usually gets progressively worse.
As pain in the groin and pelvis can be referred from a number of problems, including injuries to the lumbar spine, the hip joint, the sacro-iliac joint, the abdomen, and the genito-urinary system, diagnosis of athletic pubalgia requires skillful differentiation and pubic examination in certain cases where there is intense groin pain.
==Diagnosis== The diagnosis is based on the patient's history, clinical signs, and, increasingly, an [[MRI]] exam.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://orthopedics.about.com/od/sportsinjuries/a/hernia.htm |title=Sports Hernia |publisher=Orthopedics.about.com |date=2005-12-16 |accessdate=2011-11-13}}</ref> Symptoms can often be reproduced by maneuvers such as performing sit-ups or crunches. Pain can also be elicited with the patient in a "frog position," in which the patient is [[Supine position|supine]] with knees bent and heels together.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Le Blanc|first=E|author2=LeBlanc KA|title=Groin pain in athletes|journal=Hernia|year=2003|volume=7|issue=2|pages=68–71|pmid=12820026|doi=10.1007/s10029-002-0105-x}}</ref>
The exact lesion may differ, but common [[pathology|pathologic]] findings at operation are: * torn [[Aponeurosis of the Obliquus externus abdominis|external oblique aponeurosis]] * tear in the [[conjoint tendon]] * conjoint tendon torn from [[pubic tubercle]] * dehiscence between conjoined tendon and [[inguinal ligament]] * tear in the fascia transversalis<ref name=joesting>{{cite journal | author = Joesting DR | year = 2002 | title = Diagnosis and treatment of sportsman's hernia | url = | journal = Curr Sports Med Rep | volume = 1 | issue = 2| pages = 121–4 | pmid = 12831721 }}</ref> * abnormal insertion of the [[rectus abdominis muscle]] * tear of the [[abdominal internal oblique muscle]] from the pubic tubercle * entrapment of the [[ilioinguinal nerve]] or [[genitofemoral nerve]]<ref name="eMedicine">{{eMedicine|sports|162}}</ref> Several of these lesions may occur simultaneously. Also, many athletes have concomitant weakness or tearing of the adductor muscles or labral tears of the hip. When the adductor muscles are tight post injury, that can be enough to trigger symptoms.
==Treatment== Conservative therapies (gentle [[stretching]] and a short period of rest<ref name=GPnotebook>{{Cite GPnotebook|1161101375|athletic pubalgia}}</ref>) may temporarily alleviate the pain, but definitive treatment consists of surgical repair followed by a structured rehabilitation.<ref name="eMedicine"/><ref name="Harley">"[http://www.108harleystreet.co.uk/Pages/gilmore-groin-hernia-clinic.htm The Gilmore Groin & Hernia Clinic]". Retrieved November 24, 2006.</ref> The first conservative treatment option should be to restore normal motion after the adductor has begun to heal (usually 6–8 weeks post injury). Sleeping in a prone position with the hip on the affected side flexed and externally rotated can be a cure in some individuals.{{citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=August 2015}} ==Incidence== The exact [[incidence (epidemiology)|incidence]] of these entities is unknown: some believe it is the most common cause of chronic groin pain in athletes, while others argue that it is only rare.<ref name=fiction>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fredberg U, Kissmeyer-Nielsen P | year = 1996 | title = The sportsman's hernia—fact or fiction? | url = | journal = Scand J Med Sci Sports | volume = 6 | issue = 4| pages = 201–4 | pmid = 8896091 | doi=10.1111/j.1600-0838.1996.tb00091.x}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = {{ICD9|848.8}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }} {{Dislocations, sprains and strains}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = BBVA Compass Field | nickname = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = 800 11th Street South
[[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham, AL]] | coordinates = {{Coord|33.4980615|-86.8125946|type:landmark_region:US-AL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = October 2015 | renovated = | expanded = 2018 | owner = UAB | operator = UAB | surface = grass | scoreboard = | cost = | capacity = 5,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[UAB Blazers]] [[UAB Blazers men's soccer|men's]] & women's soccer ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2015–present)
[[Birmingham Legion FC]] ([[USL Championship|USLC]]) (2019–future) | embedded = | website = }} '''BBVA Compass Field''' is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] located in [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], [[Alabama]], United States on the campus of the [[University of Alabama at Birmingham]] (UAB) that has served as the home field for both the [[UAB Blazers]] [[UAB Blazers men's soccer|men's]] and women's soccer teams since its opening in October 2015 as the replacement for [[West Campus Field]].{{cite web|last1=Bakken|first1=Jim|title=Birmingham’s newest sports venue, BBVA Compass Field at UAB, officially debuts|url=https://www.uab.edu/news/campus/item/6810-birmingham-s-newest-sports-venue-bbva-compass-field-at-uab-officially-debuts|website=UAB News|publisher=University of Alabama at Birmingham|accessdate=April 1, 2018|ref=UAB1|date=December 9, 2015}} Development of the stadium was facilitated after [[BBVA Compass]] made a $1.5 million donation to the university for its construction in November 2014.{{cite web|title=$1.5 million BBVA Compass gift supports on-campus soccer facility at UAB|url=http://newsroom.bbvacompass.com/2014-11-07-BBVA-Compass-gift-supports-on-campus-soccer-facility-at-UAB|publisher=BBVA Compass|accessdate=April 1, 2018|date=November 7, 2014}} In February 2018, the [[University of Alabama System|Board of Trustees]] approved a $7.3 million expansion of the facility from 2,500 to 5,000 seats.{{cite news|last1=Goodman|first1=Joseph|title=Soccer team Birmingham Legion FC has a home, new stadium coming|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2018/02/soccer_team_birmingham_legion.html|accessdate=April 1, 2018|work=AL.com|agency=Alabama Media Group|date=February 8, 2018}} The expansion was financed in part by the [[Birmingham Legion FC]] who agreed to an eight-year lease to play at the stadium starting in 2019 for $350,000 annually. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{University of Alabama at Birmingham}} {{Conference USA soccer venue navbox}} {{Birmingham Legion FC}} [[Category:Soccer venues in Alabama]] [[Category:UAB Blazers]] [[Category:Sports venues in Birmingham, Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2015]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Alabama]]

revision.text:
[[File:HJRK A 32 - Boar spear head of Frederick IV of the Tyrol, c. 1430.jpg|right|thumb|100px|Boar spear head, c. 1430, length {{convert|42|cm|in|sp=us}}.]]
A '''boar spear''' is a [[spear]] used for [[boar hunting]]. It is relatively short and heavy and has two "[[Lug (knob)|lug]]s" or "wings" on the spearsocket behind the blade, which act as a barrier to prevent an injured and furious [[boar]] from working its way up the shaft of the spear to attack the hunter.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Strutt|first1=Joseph|title=The Sports and Pastimes of the People of England: From the Earliest Period, Including the Rural and Domestic Recreations, May Games, Mummeries, Pageants, Processions and Pompous Spectacles|date=1801|publisher=Methuen & Company|page=14|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=eJwSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA14&dq=Boar+spear&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjiu8eVh57ZAhWCB8AKHVLOCTsQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=Boar%20spear&f=false|accessdate=11 February 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Bear spear]] *[[Bohemian earspoon]] *[[Ahlspiess]]
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Boar spears}} *[http://sunrisecustomknives.com/field-tests/field-test-jim-casselman/ Sunrise River Custom Knives]—Jim Casselman's account of a boar hunt with spears.
{{Pole weapons}}

[[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | | location = [[Barysaw]], [[Belarus]] | coordinates = {{coord|54|11|35|N|28|28|31|E|region:BY}} | broke_ground = 2011–2014 | opened = 3 May 2014 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[FC BATE Borisov|BATE Barysaw]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = 40,000,000 [[Euro|€]][http://www.ofis-a.si/str_3%20-%20PUBLIC/05_FOOTBALL_STADIUM_FC_BATE/ofis_FOOTBALL_STADIUM_FC_BATE.html OFIS Architects (Ofis-a.si)] | architect = [[OFIS Architects]] | tenants = [[FC BATE Borisov]] (2014–)
[[Belarus national football team]] (2014–2017) | seating_capacity = 13,126{{cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/blr/borisov_arena|publisher=StadiumDB|title=Borisov Arena|accessdate=12 October 2014}} | record_attendance = 13,121 ([[Belarus national football team|Belarus]] vs [[Spain national football team|Spain]], 25 June 2015)[http://www.uefa.org/newsfiles/ucl/2015/md03_1_fs.pdf Full Time Summary Matchday 3 – Tuesday 20 October 2014"]. UEFA.org. 20 October 2014. | dimensions = 105 x 68m }} '''Borisov Arena''' is a [[football-specific stadium]] in [[Barysaw]], [[Belarus]] and is the home stadium of [[FC BATE Borisov]] and the [[Belarus national football team]]. The stadium's official capacity is 13,126.[http://www.fcbate.by/en/club/stadium/borisov-arena Borisov Arena at FCBate.by][http://www.fcbate.by/ru/infocenter/club-news/id1810 Season tickets on sale 20 Jan (FCBate.by)] ==History== The first official game ever played at the Borisov Arena was the [[2013–14 Belarusian Cup#Final|2013–14 Belarusian Cup Final]] on May 3, 2014. It was contested between [[FC Neman Grodno]] and [[FC Shakhtyor Soligorsk]] and won 1-0 by the team from Salihorsk. [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[midfielder]] [[Artem Starhorodskyi]] scored the first ever goal on the stadium in front of an almost full capacity of over 11,000. ==National team matches== The Belarus national football team played its first game at the Borisov Arena on September 4, 2014, when they defeated [[Tajikistan national football team|Tajikistan]] 6-1 in a friendly.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/09/04/world/friendlies/belarus/tajikistan/1667837/|title=Belarus vs. Tajikistan 6:1|publisher=Soccerway.com|accessdate=12 October 2014}} The first official national team game was played on October 9, 2014, when Belarus lost 0-2 to [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] in a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group C|UEFA Euro 2016 qualifier]] played in front of 10,512 spectators.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/10/09/europe/european-championship-qualification/belarus/ukraine/1653169/|title=Belarus vs. Ukraine 0:2|publisher=Soccerway.com|accessdate=12 October 2014}} ===List of games=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" ! # ! Date ! Opponent ! Result ! Attendance ! Competition |- | 1. | September 4, 2014 | {{flagicon|Tajikistan}} [[Tajikistan national football team|Tajikistan]] | bgcolor="#ddffdd" style="text-align:center;"| '''6–1''' | style="text-align:center;"| 2,400 | Friendly |- | 2. | October 9, 2014 | {{flagicon|Ukraine}} [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] | bgcolor="#ffdddd" style="text-align:center;"| '''0–2''' | style="text-align:center;"| 10,512 | [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group C|UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] |- | 3. | October 12, 2014 | {{flagicon|Slovakia}} [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] | bgcolor="#ffdddd" style="text-align:center;"| '''1–3''' | style="text-align:center;"| 3,684{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/10/12/europe/european-championship-qualification/belarus/slovakia/1653196/|title=Belarus vs. SLOVAKIA 1 - {{Infobox rugby team | teamname = CDUP | image = | fullname = Centro Desportivo Universitario do Porto | founded = 1964| ground = Estádio Universitário do Porto| capacity = | chairman = | coach = {{flagicon|PRT}} Marcello d'Orey | league = [[Campeonato Nacional Honra/Super Bock]] | season = 2011-12 | position = 6th | pattern_la1=_white_shoulders|pattern_b1=_thinwhitesides|pattern_ra1=_white_shoulders|pattern_sh1=_white stripes| pattern_so1=_band_white | leftarm1=01796F|body1=01796F|rightarm1=01796F|shorts1=01796F|socks1=01796F| }}
'''Centro Desportivo Universitário do Porto''' or '''CDUP''' (Sports Center of [[University of Porto]]) is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] amateur sports club for students at the [[University of Porto]], in [[Porto]], [[Portugal]].
==History==
=== The dispute resolution with the [[University of Porto]] (2012 – Present) === On November 2012, CDUP and the [[University of Porto]] reached an agreement to settle the dispute they have been having since 2003, due to the refuse of the University to support and fund the federated sports side of the club.<ref>https://desporto.sapo.pt/mais_modalidades/artigo/2012/11/21/cdup-e-universidade-do-porto-chegam-a-acordo-ao-fim-de-nove-anos</ref>
Resulting from this agreement, the [[University of Porto]] published, in January 2013, the articles of association of a new autonomous service of the University called "CDUP-UP - Centro de Desporto da Universidade do Porto" with the responsibility of promoting and organizing university sports.
CDUP remained juridical autonomous from the [[University of Porto]], although without the responsibility of university sports. Because of that, it was proposed to change its name to "CDUP-AD - Centro Desportivo Universitário do Porto, associação desportiva autónoma" and it became responsible only for federated non university sports, with the condition that, at least 50% of the total registered athletes, must be part of the academic community.<ref>https://dre.pt/application/file/3584803</ref>
Until today, the club name hasn’t changed and it is still called "CDUP - Centro Desportivo Universitário do Porto".
==Sports==
CDUP enables students to practise a large number of sports and has sections dedicated to several sports at the competitive level, including [[athletics (track and field)|athletics]], [[Team handball|handball]], [[badminton]], [[basketball]], [[Contract bridge|bridge]], [[canoeing]], [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[water polo]], [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]], [[table tennis]], [[tennis]], [[volleyball]], [[chess]], and the sport for which they are best known in [[Portugal]] — [[Rugby union|rugby]].
The CDUP team is one of the best Portuguese rugby union teams and three of its players were included in the Portuguese squad for the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]]. In Portugal, rugby is considered a traditional university sport.
==Facilities==
CDUP facilities are located in two places in the city — the University Stadium and the Rua da Boa Hora. The CDUP headquarters are located in the Rua da Boa Hora n.º 20 (20, Boa Hora street) where there is also a swimming pool, rooms for martial arts, [[gymnastics]], chess and table tennis. At the University Stadium, by the [[Arrábida Bridge]], there are a multisports arena with two indoor sports fields, two tennis courts, an outdoor [[futsal]] field, and in stadium one athletics tartan track and one [[association football|football]]/[[Rugby union|rugby]] grass pitch.
==Honors==
*'''[[Taça de Portugal de Rugby]]''': **'''Winner (3)''': 2002-03, 2006–07 *Athletics Portuguese Championship 1994: 3rd Place
{{CN Honra/Super Bock}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox mythical creature |name = Champ |image = Artistic representation of Sandra Mansi's 1977 photograph of "Champ" lake monster.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = Artistic representation of Sandra Mansi's 1977 photograph of the Lake Champlain Monster. Illustration by [[Benjamin Radford]]. |Grouping = |Sub_Grouping = [[Lake Monster]] / [[Sea Serpent]] |AKA = Lake Champlain Monster |Country = United States, Canada |Region = [[Lake Champlain]] |Habitat = Water |Status = }}
In [[Folklore of the United States|American folklore]], '''Champ''' or '''Champy'''<ref name=pr>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressrepublican.com/news/local_news/gordie-little-writes-children-s-book/article_53f2213e-24b2-5df9-8477-0dfbff1102ec.html |title=Gordie Little writes children's book |last=Caudell |first=Robin |work=Press-Republican |date=Nov 5, 2011 |accessdate=Dec 9, 2014}}</ref> is the name of a [[lake monster]] said to live in [[Lake Champlain]], a {{convert|125|mi|km|adj=on}}-long body of fresh water shared by [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Vermont]], with a portion extending into [[Quebec]], Canada.<ref name="Ogopogo Country">{{cite web|url=http://cnc.virtuelle.ca/ogopogo/lake_creature/champ.html|title=Canada's Lake Creature: Champ|year=2001|accessdate=25 October 2009|work=Welcome to Ogopogo Country|publisher=Centre culturel Marie-Anne-Gaboury |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050302182625/http://cnc.virtuelle.ca/ogopogo/lake_creature/champ.html |archivedate= 2005-03-02}}</ref> The legend of the monster is considered a draw for tourism in the [[Burlington, Vermont]] and [[Plattsburgh, New York]] areas.
[[File:Champlainmap.svg|upright=1.25|thumb|Map of Lake Champlain watershed]]
== History of the legend == Over the years, there have been over 300 reported sightings of Champ.<ref name="LCLT">{{cite web|url=http://lclt.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=32&Itemid=40|title=Champ, the Famed Monster of Lake Champlain|accessdate=25 October 2009|publisher=Lake Champlain Land Trust |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100407095515/http://www.lclt.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=32&Itemid=40 |archivedate= 2010-04-07}}</ref> Legends of a creature living in Lake Champlain date back to Native American tribes in the region, with both the [[Iroquois]] and the [[Abenaki]] speaking of such a creature.{{cn|date=May 2018}} The Abenaki referred to it as "Tatoskok".<ref name="Lake Champlain Region">{{cite web|url=http://www.lakechamplainregion.com/content_pages/champyhistory.cfm |title=Champ History – From Ancient Times|accessdate=14 December 2006|publisher=Lake Champlain Visitors Center|work=Lake Champlain Region |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080215094635/http://www.lakechamplainregion.com/content_pages/champyhistory.cfm |archivedate = 15 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://goadirondack.com/sub_menu_page.php?sub_menu_id=133 |title=The Legend of Champ |work=The Adirondack Coast |publisher=Adirondack Coast Visitors & Convention Bureau |accessdate=25 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070730204024/http://goadirondack.com/sub_menu_page.php?sub_menu_id=133# |archivedate=2007-07-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="VT Secretary of State">{{cite web|url=http://www.sec.state.vt.us/Kids/champ.html|publisher=Vermont Secretary of State|title=Sea Monsters in Vermont|accessdate=25 October 2009|work=Kids Pages|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030134118/http://www.sec.state.vt.us/kids/champ.html#|archive-date=2009-10-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Tourism websites|date=May 2018}}
[[Samuel de Champlain]], the founder of Québec and the lake's namesake, is often claimed to be the first European to have sighted Champ, in 1609. However, this legend dates back to a fake quote published in the Summer 1970 issue of Vermont Life. In the Vermont Life article, Champlain is alleged to have documented a "20-foot serpent thick as a barrel, and a head like a horse." This quote has often been repeated, but is in fact apocryphal. Champlain did document large fish: {{quote|There is also a great abundance of fish, of many varieties: among others, one called by the savages of the country ''Chaoufarou'', which varies in length, the largest being, as the people told me, eight or ten feet long. I saw some five feet long, which were as large as my thigh; the head being as big as my two fists, with a snout two feet and half long, and a double row of very sharp and dangerous teeth. Its body is, in shape, very much like that of a pike; but it is armed with scales so strong and a poniard could not piece them. Its color is silver-gray.}} The 1878 translation of his journals clarifies that ''Chaoufaou'' refers to [[Gar|gar (or gar pike)]], specifically ''[[Longnose gar|Lepisosteus osseus]]'' (the longnose gar).<ref name="Champlain1878">{{cite book |last=de Champlain|first=Samuel |author-link=Samuel de Champlain |translator-last1=Otis |translator-first1=Charles Pomeroy |translator-link=Charles Pomeroy Otis |title=Voyages of Samuel de Champlain |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q_kWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA216 |year=1878 |publisher=Prince Society |location=Boston, Massachusetts |volume=2: 1604-1610 |pages=215–217}}</ref>
An 1819 report in the Plattsburgh Republican, entitled "Cape Ann Serpent on Lake Champlain", reports a "Capt. Crum" sighting an enormous serpentine monster.<ref name='CRUM'>{{cite news |last=Mackerel |first=Horse |title=Cape Ann Serpent on Lake Champlain |date=24 July 1819 |url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn83031979/1819-07-24/ed-1/seq-2/ |newspaper=Plattsburgh Republican |publisher= |location=Plattsburgh, New York |volume=9 |issue=17 |page=2 |via=NYS Historic Newspapers}}</ref><ref name='LCEPVB'>{{cite web|url=http://lakeplacidmedia.com/uploads/PDF/Champ.pdf |title=The Search for Champ |accessdate=2010-04-03 |publisher=Lake Placid/Essex County Visitor's Bureau }}</ref> Crum estimated the monster to have been about 187-feet long and approximately two hundred yards away from him. Despite the great distance, he claimed to have witnessed it being followed by "two large Sturgeon and a Bill-fish" and was able to see that it had three teeth and eyes the color of peeled onions. He also described the monster as having "a belt of red" around its neck and a white star on its forehead.<ref name="csicop.org">{{cite web|last1=Joe|first1=Nickell|authorlink=Joe Nickell|title=Legend of the Lake Champlain Monster|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/legend_of_the_lake_champlain_monster/|website=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]|publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref>
In 1883, Sheriff Nathan H. Mooney claimed that he had seen a water serpent about "20 rods" from where he was on the shore. He claimed that he was so close that he could see "round white spots inside its mouth" and that "the creature appeared to be about 25 to 30 feet in length". Mooney's sighting led to many more alleged eyewitnesses coming forward with their own accounts of Champ.<ref name="Hall1999">{{cite book |last=Hall |first=Dennis Jay |title=Champ Quest 1999: The Ultimate Search |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=OkdqCQAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA59 |date=June 1999 |publisher=Essence of Vermont |isbn=978-1-928837-00-8 |page=55}}</ref>
The legend of Champ captured the interest of [[P. T. Barnum]], and in 1873<ref>{{cite news |editor-last=Wheelock |editor-first=J. W. |title=Vermont News |date=27 August 1873 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/365924268/ |newspaper=The Green Mountain Freeman |publisher= |location=Monpelier, Vermont |volume=30 |issue=35 |page=3 |quote=I hereby offer $50,000 for the hide of the great Champlain Serpent to add to my Mammoth World's Fair Show. |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref> and 1887<ref>{{cite news |author=Staff writer |title=After a Sea Serpent |date=5 August 1887 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/86365643/ |newspaper=The Daily Post |publisher= |location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania |volume=45 |issue= |page=4 |quote=P.T. Barnum believes that a huge sea serpent exists, and has renewed his offer of $20,000 for the reptile. |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref>, the famous showman offered rewards for anyone who could bring him the monster.<ref name="csicop.org"/>
[[File:Benjamin Radford and Joe Nickell with Champ eyewitness & photographer Sandra Mansi.jpg|left|upright=1.5|thumb|Sandra Mansi with investigators [[Joe Nickell]] and [[Benjamin Radford]]]]
== Mansi photograph == In 1977, Sandra Mansi took a photograph while on vacation with her family that appears to show something sticking out of the lake.<ref name="Fortean Times">{{cite web|last=Radford|first=Benjamin|authorlink=Benjamin Radford|date=April 2004|title=Lake Champlain Monster|publisher=Fortean Times|accessdate=25 October 2009}}</ref> The entire bay of the lake where the photograph reportedly was taken is no deeper than {{convert|14|ft|m}}. According to [[Joe Nickell]], it is unlikely that a giant creature could swim, let alone hide, in such shallow water.<ref name="CSI"/> It has been suggested that the object in the photograph could possibly be a rising tree trunk or log.<ref name="Legend of the Lake Champlain Monster">{{cite web|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/legend_of_the_lake_champlain_monster/|title=Legend of the Lake Champlain Monster|last=Nickell|first=Joe|authorlink=Joe Nickell|accessdate=31 October 2010|publisher=The Committee for Skeptical Inquiry}}</ref>
== Recent reports == Champ reportedly can be seen in a video taken by fishermen Dick Affolter and his stepson Pete Bodette in the summer of 2005.<ref name="VOA">{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Adam|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/a-13-2006-03-21-voa14.html|title=Is Lake Champlain Home to a Sea Serpent?|date=21 March 2006|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|accessdate=25 October 2009}}</ref> Close examination of the images may be interpreted either as a head and neck of a plesiosaur-like animal and even an open mouth in one frame and a closed mouth in another; or as a fish or eel. Although two retired [[FBI]] forensic image analysts, who reviewed the tape, said it appears authentic and unmanipulated, one of them added that "there's no place in there that I can actually see an animal or any other object on the surface".<ref name="ABC News">{{cite web|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=1648547&page=1|title=Is There a Monster in Lake Champlain?|date=22 February 2008|accessdate=25 October 2009|publisher=[[ABC News]]|work=[[Good Morning America|GMA]]}}</ref>
One piece of evidence, though not a "sighting" per se, is the recording of sounds from within the lake by the Fauna Communications Research Institute in 2003, working as part of a [[Discovery Channel]] program. The group described the sounds as being similar to those produced by Beluga whales or dolphins—neither of which are known to live in Lake Champlain.<ref name="Fauna Communications">{{cite web|url=|title=Lake's First 'Champ-Hearing' Recorded|date=July 2003|accessdate=13 March 2014|publisher=Burlington Free Press}}</ref> An article describing the recordings has been published to scientific literature.<ref>{{cite web|title=Echolocation in a fresh water lake|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/asa/journal/jasa/127/3/10.1121/1.3384449|website=Acoustical Society of America}}</ref> Based upon appearance and "mysterious alligatorlike tracks" found near Lake Champlain, cryptozoologists Katy Elizabeth and Dennis Hall suggested in 2016 that "Champ" could be a member of the family Crocodylidae (crocodiles). Researcher Scott Mardis explains that the tracks were likely the tracks of a large snapping turtle and also mentions the Longnose Gar or the Lake Sturgeon as more probable candidates for "Champ."<ref name="Croc">{{cite journal|last1=Mardis|first1=Scott|editor1-last=Radford|editor1-first=Benjamin|title=A Champlain 'Croc' of Mythic Proportions|journal=Skeptical Briefs|date=Fall 2016|volume=26|issue=3|page=4|publisher=Center for Inquiry}}</ref>
== Cultural importance to New York and Vermont == [[File:Champmascot.JPG|right|thumb|Vermont Lake Monsters mascot]] The Champ legend has become a revenue-generating attraction.<ref name='CSI'>{{cite web|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/legend_of_the_lake_champlain_monster/ |title=Legend of the Lake Champlain Monster |accessdate=2010-04-03 |last=Joe |first=Nickell|authorlink=Joe Nickell |date=July–August 2003 |work=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|CSI]] }}</ref> For example, the village of [[Port Henry, New York|Port Henry]], New York, has erected a giant model of Champ and holds "Champ Day" on the first Saturday of every August. As the mascot of Vermont's lone Minor League Baseball affiliate, the [[Vermont Lake Monsters]], Champ became more prominent after the team was renamed from the Vermont Expos to the Vermont Lake Monsters following the 2005 season. Champ has been the primary attraction of the [[New York–Penn League]] affiliate since their inception. Several nearby establishments, including a car wash, use images of Champ as a logo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.champcarwash.com/AboutUs.aspx|title=Champ Touchless Car Wash|website=Champ Touchless Car Wash|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Mussie]] *[[Lake Tianchi Monster]] *[[Ogopogo]] *[[Mokele mbembe]] *[[Selma (lake monster)]] *[[Memphre]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

{{Burlington, Vermont}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Estadio Municipal Germán Becker | nickname = Estadio Germán Becker | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = 100OLYMP1.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Interior of the stadium | fullname = Estadio Municipal Bicentenario German Becker Baechler | former_names = | location = [[Temuco]], [[Chile]] | coordinates = {{coord|38|44|34|S|72|37|11|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = {{Start date|1965|03|15}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|1965|08|13}} | reopened = {{Start date|2008|11|05}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of [[Temuco]] | operator = | surface = grass | scoreboard = | cost = [[Chilean peso|$]] 16,866,360,960 ([[United States dollar|$]] 34.4 million) -reconstruction- | architect = Sergio Ferreira P.
Madrid Roberto L. | project_manager = | structural engineer = Eduardo Rodriguez | services engineer = | general_contractor = Socovesa | main_contractors = | capacity = 18,413{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/copa-america-2015|title=Copa América 2015|work=conmebol.com}} | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Deportes Temuco]] | embedded = | website = }} The '''Estadio Municipal Bicentenario Germán Becker Baechler''' is a stadium located in [[Temuco]], [[Chile]] and owned by the Temuco municipality. It is the home ground of [[Deportes Temuco]] and also, the former ground of the defunct [[Unión Temuco]] football clubs. It was designed by Enrique Esteve and inaugurated on August 13, 1965. Its dimensions are: 105 x 68 m. It has a capacity of 18,413. It was originally built for the inmates at the Temuco prison. The highest ever recorded attendance was in December 3, 1972 when 32,551 spectators saw the [[Chilean Primera División|Primera Division]] match between [[Deportes Temuco|Green Cross Temuco]] and [[Colo-Colo]]. In 2007 the stadium was selected as a venue for the [[2008 FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup]], and to comply with [[FIFA]] standards, its facilities were improved, its capacity was decreased from 20,930 to 18,936; and all seats were covered by a roof (from about 80% previously). The athletics track was removed to enhance spectators' enjoyment of the on-the-pitch action. The stadium was re-inaugurated on November 5, 2008. In 2013 the stadium was the main venue for the [[2013 IRB Junior World Rugby Trophy|IRB Junior World Rugby Trophy]]. In April 27, 2013 it hosted a [[2015 Rugby World Cup qualifying]] match between hosts nation [[Chile national rugby union team|Chile]] and [[Brazil national rugby union team|Brazil]]. Chile won 38 - 22 with 10,000 in attendance. In 2015, three [[Copa América]] matches were played at the stadium. ==Gallery== File:Estadio Germán Becker.jpg|Stadium prior to renovation ==2015 Copa América== {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[Time in Chile|UTC-3]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |June 14, 2015||18:30||{{fb|BRA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|[[2015 Copa América Group C#Brazil vs Peru|2–1]]||{{fb|PER}} ||[[2015 Copa América Group C|Group C]]||style="text-align:center;"|16,342 |- |June 21, 2015||16:00||{{fb|COL}} ||style="text-align:center;"|[[2015 Copa América Group C#Colombia vs Peru|0–0]]|||{{fb|PER}} ||[[2015 Copa América Group C|Group C]]||style="text-align:center;"|17,332 |- |June 25, 2015||20:30||{{fb|BOL}} ||style="text-align:center;"|[[2015 Copa América knockout stage#Bolivia vs Peru|1–3]]||{{fb|PER}} ||[[2015 Copa América knockout stage|Quarter-Finals]]||style="text-align:center;"|16,872 |} {{Primera División de Chile Venues}} {{2015 Copa América stadiums}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.fifa.com/u20womenworldcup/destination/stadiums/stadium=5016407/index.html FIFA site] *[http://www.visitanyplace.com/panoramic/showqtvrfs.php?file=CHL.TEMUCO.ESTADIO.FUTBOL Old Stadium Panorama view] ([[QTVR]]) {{DEFAULTSORT:Estadio Municipal German Becker}} [[Category:Football venues in Chile|German Becker]] [[Category:Sports venues in La Araucanía Region]] [[Category:Temuco]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1965]] {{Chile-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Fever Pitch | image = Fever Pitch US.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = {{ubl|[[Farrelly brothers|Peter Farrelly
Bobby Farrelly]]}} | producer = {{ubl|[[Amanda Posey]]|Alan Greenspan|Gil Netter|[[Drew Barrymore]]|[[Nancy Juvonen]]|Bradley Thomas}} | screenplay = {{ubl|[[Lowell Ganz]]|[[Babaloo Mandel]]}} | based on = {{basedon|''[[Fever Pitch|Fever Pitch: A Fan's Life]]''|[[Nick Hornby]]}} | starring = [[Drew Barrymore]]
[[Jimmy Fallon]] | music = [[Craig Armstrong (composer)|Craig Armstrong]] | cinematography = [[Matthew F. Leonetti]] | editing = [[Alan Baumgarten]] | studio = {{ubl|[[Flower Films]]|Conundrum Entertainment}} | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|2005|4|6|[[Boston]]|2005|4|8|United States}} | runtime = 103 minutes | language = English | budget = $30 million | gross = $50.5 million }} '''''Fever Pitch''''' (released as '''''The Perfect Catch''''' outside the United States and Canada) is a 2005 [[romantic comedy]] film. It is directed by the [[Farrelly brothers]], and stars [[Drew Barrymore]] and [[Jimmy Fallon]]. It is a [[remake]] of the [[Fever Pitch (1997 film)|1997 film]]. [[Nick Hornby]], who had written the original [[Fever Pitch|book]] and the 1997 screenplay adaptation, acted as an executive producer for the American remake.{{cite news|work=IMDb|title=Fever Pitch: Produced By|date=2005|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332047/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm}} While both the book and the original 1997 film are about [[association football]], the 2005 adaptation, aimed at the U.S. market, is about [[baseball]]. Both ''Fever Pitch'' films feature real-life dramatic or unexpected sporting victories, the original focusing on [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal's]] last minute [[Liverpool 0–2 Arsenal (26 May 1989)|League title win]] in 1989, and the remake on the [[Boston Red Sox]]'s [[2004 World Series]] Championship. ==Plot== Ben Wrightman, a 7-year-old boy, is going to a [[Boston Red Sox|Red Sox]] game with his Uncle Carl. His uncle, who had no children of his own, treated Ben like a son. A narration explains that on that day, Ben became a [[Red Sox Nation|die-hard Red Sox fan]]. Just about everything he owns bears the Red Sox name, emblem, or image of a Red Sox player (with the exception of his toilet paper, which bears the [[New York Yankees]] insignia). Ben inherited his uncle's season tickets when Carl died from cancer. The story picks up 23 years later with Ben ([[Jimmy Fallon]]) as a school teacher who is immature for his age. He meets Lindsey Meeks ([[Drew Barrymore]]), a professionally successful workaholic executive. When Ben first asks her out, Lindsey rejects him, but she later changes her mind and agrees to go out with him. On their [[First date (meeting)|first date]], Ben finds Lindsey very sick and vomiting. She has [[food poisoning]] from a new restaurant where she had dined earlier that day. Ben decides to spend the night and take care of her, as well as clean up her bathroom (whimsically telling her it was the "Vomit Elves" that did the work). The next morning, Lindsey, feeling better, finds Ben sleeping on her couch. Ben awakens, and he and Lindsey end up developing a romantic relationship. Overcoming her initial hesitance, Lindsey becomes attracted to Ben because of his ability to show passionate commitment to something. That spring, he later pretends he is proposing to her but instead asks her to the Red Sox [[Opening Day]], where [[Stephen King]] (a longtime Sox fan) throws the first pitch. Lindsey attends, but not being a baseball or Red Sox fan, she knows nothing about the [[Curse of the Bambino]] or even how to pronounce the name [[Carl Yastrzemski|Yastrzemski]]. The two continue attending the games together until one summer night when Lindsey attempts to catch up on work by taking her laptop to the game. Not paying attention to the game, she is knocked out by a [[line drive]] [[foul ball]] by then [[Baltimore Orioles]] [[shortstop]] [[Miguel Tejada]] off [[Mike Myers (baseball)|Mike Myers]] (which ends up making the late night sports highlight reel). She eventually recovers but stops going to the games. Things take a turn for the worse when Lindsey invites Ben to accompany her to Paris, and he declines the offer because the Red Sox are in the heat of the playoff race. Before leaving for Paris, she tells Ben she is "late" and may be pregnant with his child, though they later learns she is not. Lindsey starts to become fed up with Ben's [[Fixation (psychology)|obsession]] with the Red Sox. Ben agrees to miss a game [[Yankees–Red Sox rivalry|against the Yankees]] in order to escort Lindsey to her friend's birthday party. Ben and Lindsey have a wonderful time together, and after making love, he tells her it was one of the best nights of his life. Moments later, Ben receives a call from his ecstatic friend Troy, who informs him that the Red Sox overcame a seven run deficit in the bottom of the ninth inning to pull off one of the greatest comebacks in team history. Ben becomes irate that he missed such an historic Red Sox moment, greatly hurting Lindsey's feelings. After Lindsey miserably declares he has broken her heart, he and Lindsey separate for a while. Ben soon misses Lindsey and visits her in a futile attempt to reconcile. He eventually feels her loss so deeply that he plans to sell his season tickets to Chris, the husband of Lindsey's friend Robin (for $125,000 – the price for which Red Sox owner [[Harry Frazee]] sold [[Babe Ruth]] to the Yankees in 1920), in order to prove that Lindsey means more to him than the Red Sox do. Lindsey finds out about his plan during the celebration for her much-anticipated promotion. Immediately leaving the celebration, she rushes to the ballpark to try to stop Ben. She gets in during the 8th inning of the Red Sox—Yankees playoff game when the Sox are just three outs away from being swept. Ben is actually in the process of signing a contract with Chris as they sit in the stands. Because she is unable to reach Ben from her section in [[Fenway Park]] in time to stop Ben from signing the contract, Lindsey illegally runs across the field, deftly avoiding security personnel by running behind outfielder [[Johnny Damon]] (and throwing his glove at them) until she finally reaches Ben. She tears Chris' contract in pieces and explains that if Ben loves her enough to sell his seats, then she loves him enough not to allow him to do so. The two reunite and kiss in front of the entire crowd. The narrator (Al Waterman) explains how the Red Sox won that game and then beat the Yankees three more times to win the [[American League]] [[Pennant (sports)|pennant]], later sweeping the [[National League]] champion [[St. Louis Cardinals]] in four games for their first [[World Series]] title in 86 years, with Lindsay and Ben traveling to [[Busch Stadium (II)|Busch Stadium]] in St. Louis for the decisive Game 4. The two of them also get married, and she gets pregnant. Al explains that the baby will be named after one of the players: [[Ted Williams]] Wrightman if it's a boy, Carla Yastrzemski Wrightman (for [[Carl Yastrzemski]]) if it's a girl, with the narration jokingly hoping for a boy. ==Cast== ===Actors=== * [[Jimmy Fallon]] as Ben Wrightman * [[Drew Barrymore]] as Lindsey Meeks * [[James Sikking]] as Doug Meeks * [[JoBeth Williams]] as Maureen Meeks * [[Jason Spevack]] as Ben in 1980 * Jack Kehler as Al Waterman (also the narrator) * [[Lenny Clarke]] as Uncle Carl * [[Ione Skye]] as Molly * [[Siobhan Fallon Hogan]] as Lana * [[KaDee Strickland]] as Robin * [[Marissa Jaret Winokur]] as Sarah * [[Evan Helmuth]] as Troy * [[Zen Gesner]] as Steve * [[Jackie Burroughs]] as Mrs. Warren * [[Stephen King]] as Himself * [[Kris Williams (investigator)|Kris Williams]] as Herself * [[Steve Levy]] as Himself * [[Willie Garson]] as Kevin * [[Armando Riesco]] as Gerard * [[Brett Murphy]] as Ryan * [[Andrew Wilson (actor)|Andrew Wilson]] as Grant Wade / Patrick Lyons Several [[Boston Red Sox]] personnel make appearances in the film, including: players [[Johnny Damon]], [[Trot Nixon]], [[Jason Varitek]] and [[Jim Rice]], and announcers [[Joe Castiglione]], [[Don Orsillo]] and [[Dennis Eckersley]]. ==Production== The original plot had assumed the [[Boston Red Sox|Red Sox]] would lose in the playoffs. However, the Sox stunned the baseball world when they won four straight games to win the [[2004 American League Championship Series|2004 ALCS]] against the rival [[New York Yankees|Yankees]] (becoming the first [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] team to win a seven-game series after losing the first three games) and subsequent [[2004 World Series|World Series]] against the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] to break the "[[Curse of the Bambino]]." Thus, the ending had to be rewritten. On the day of Game 4, with the Red Sox on the verge of a sweep, The Farrellys decided to bring Barrymore, Fallon, and a film crew to St. Louis hours before the first pitch – and Barrymore and Fallon attended the game at [[Busch Stadium II|Busch Stadium]] in character. When the Red Sox made the final out to secure a 4-0 win over the Cardinals that broke the Curse, FOX cameras on the live broadcast caught Barrymore and Fallon, as Lindsey and Ben, running onto the field and kissing to celebrate.{{cite news |title = Sox Change |url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,767456,00.html |work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | first=Whitney |last=Pastorek |date=November 12, 2004}} The film, with its updated ending, was also screened at Fenway Park the following August as a screen was set up in center field.[http://www.boston.com/culture/entertainment/2015/07/31/you-can-watch-fever-pitch-at-fenway-in-august You can watch ''Fever Pitch'' at Fenway in August] ''[[Boston Globe]]'' via Boston.com Originally, [[Shawn Levy]], who was a huge fan of [[Nick Hornby]]'s works for years, was attached to direct, with [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] playing Lindsey.{{cite news|work=Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1405285/Can-Hornby-remake-bring-fever-pitch-to-baseball.html|title=Can Hornby Remake Bring Fever Pitch to Baseball?}} However, Paltrow found the script mediocre and turned down the role.{{cite news|url=http://www.notstarring.com/actors/paltrow-gwyneth|work=NotStarring.com|title=Gwyneth Paltrow}} [[Brian Robbins]] replaced Levy, but he quit the project as well.{{cite news|work=Variety|url=https://variety.com/2003/film/news/robbins-catches-pitch-from-fox-2000-1117886165/|date=2003|title=Robbins Catches Pitch from FOX}} After [[Drew Barrymore]] replaced Paltrow and [[Jimmy Fallon]] joined the cast, [[Jay Russell]],{{cite news|url=http://www.memphis.edu/magazinearchive/v20i3/feat3.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531200523/http://www.memphis.edu/magazinearchive/v20i3/feat3.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-05-31|title=Memphis Magazine; Feature}} [[P.J. Hogan]],{{cite web|website=MovieHole.net|url=http://moviehole.net/20044089hogan-and-barrymore-up-for-fever-pitch|title=Hogan and Barrymore Up for Fever Pitch}} [[Luke Greenfield]],{{cite news|work=TCM|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/580491/Fever-Pitch/misc-notes.html|title=Fever Pitch Miscellaneous Notes}} and [[Mira Nair]] were all rumored candidates to direct until the studios hired the [[Farrelly brothers]] to take the helm for the film. ==Reception== ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film had an average rating of 65%, based on 189 reviews, with an average rating of 6.3/10. The site's critical consensus read, "While not a home run, ''Fever Pitch'' has enough charm and on-screen chemistry between the two leads to make it a solid hit."{{cite web |title = Fever Pitch (2005) |url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/fever_pitch/ |work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher = [[Flixster]] |accessdate = September 16, 2016 }} At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Weighted mean|weighted average]] score to reviews from mainstream critics, the film received an average score of 56 out of 100, based on 37 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web |title = Fever Pitch reviews |url = http://www.metacritic.com/movie/fever-pitch |work = [[Metacritic]] |publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate = August 28, 2010 }} On [[CinemaScore]], audiences gave the film an average grade of "A–" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://m.cinemascore.com |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150405021357/http://m.cinemascore.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-04-05 |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com }} From a cinematographic and literary perspective, the film received some favorable criticism from experts [[Roger Ebert]]{{cite news | first=Roger | last=Ebert | title=''Fever Pitch'' by Roger Ebert | date=April 8, 2005 | publisher=Chicago Sun-Times | url =http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050407/REVIEWS/50323004/1023 | work =RogerEbert.com | pages = | accessdate = April 14, 2008 }} and [[James Berardinelli]].{{cite news | first=James | last=Berardinelli | title=''Fever Pitch'' - A Film Review by James Berardinelli | year=2005 | publisher= | url =http://preview.reelviews.net/movies/f/fever_pitch2005.html | work =ReelViews.com | pages = | accessdate = April 14, 2008 }} The film opened at #3 and grossed $12.4 million in its opening weekend. The final North American gross of the film was $42,071,069, and the worldwide gross was $50,451,307.{{cite web |title = Fever Pitch (2005) |url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=feverpitch.htm |work = [[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher = [[Internet Movie Database]] |accessdate = August 28, 2010 }} ===Fan response=== "Sports Guy" [[Bill Simmons]] of [[ESPN]] disliked the film because he regarded it as a "chick flick" disguising itself as a sports movie and said that no Red Sox fan would give up season tickets for love,{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} but [[Red Sox Nation]] voted to award Fallon honorary membership for playing Ben so convincingly despite Fallon being a Yankees fan.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Fever Pitch: Music from the Motion Picture | type = Soundtrack | artist = Various Artists | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|2005|4|26}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 54:23{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/fever-pitch-2005-original-soundtrack-mw0000344430|title=Fever Pitch: Music from the Motion Picture|accessdate=May 22, 2013}} | label = BulletProof Music/[[Rykodisc]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} #[[The Standells]] – "[[Dirty Water]]" #[[Dropkick Murphys]] – "[[Tessie]]" #[[Tears for Fears]] – "Who Killed Tangerine?" #[[Popium]] – "Sooner or Later" #[[Ivy (band)|Ivy]] – "Thinking About You" #[[Nick Drake]] – "[[Northern Sky]]" #[[Marah (band)|Marah]] – "My Heart Is the Bums on the Street" #[[Steve Wynn (musician)|Steve Wynn]] – "Second Best" #[[The J. Geils Band]] – "Whammer Jammer" (Live Version){{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332047/soundtrack|title=Fever Pitch (2005) – Soundtracks – IMDb}} #[[The Human League]] – "(Keep Feeling) Fascination" #[[Chic (band)|Chic]] – "Dance, Dance, Dance (Yowsah, Yowsah, Yowsah)" #[[Joe Pernice]] – "Moonshot Manny" #[[Jonathan Richman]] – "As We Walk to Fenway Park in Boston Town" #[[Mad {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} '''James Fuggles''' was an English [[cricket]]er in the 18th century. He was a [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] batsman who played in all three recorded matches in 1772 and made his final known appearance in 1773. In his four recorded appearances, he played 8 innings and scored 51 runs with a top score of 21.
He was a regular player before the sport's ''statistical record'' began in 1772 but little is known of him. There are scattered references to him playing in major matches during the 1760s.
==External links== * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/77/77397/77397.html CricketArchive record of James Fuggles] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080907032634/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/biog.html#fuggles From Lads to Lord's – biography of James Fuggles]
== References == * ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'' by [[G B Buckley]] (FL18) * ''Scores & Biographies, Volume 1'' by [[Arthur Haygarth]] (SBnnn) * ''The Dawn of Cricket'' by [[H T Waghorn]] (WDC)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fuggles, James}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:Kent cricketers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Non-international England cricketers]]
{{England-cricket-bio-stub}}

A '''lacrosse stick''' or '''crosse''' is used to play the sport of [[lacrosse]]. Players use the lacrosse stick to handle the [[lacrosse ball|ball]] and to strike or "check" opposing players' sticks, causing them to drop the ball. The head of a lacrosse stick is roughly triangular in shape and is strung with loose netting that allows the ball to be caught, carried (known as "cradling"), passed, or shot.
==Traditional stick== [[File:Wooden sticks.jpg|left|thumbnail|A pair of wood lacrosse sticks.]] A wood lacrosse stick is usually crafted from [[hickory]] trees.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/insight/2017/03/11/a-lacrosse-game-with-the-1867-touches.html "A lacrosse game with the 1867 touches"]. ''Toronto Star'', Mary Ormsby, March 11, 2017</ref> The lacrosse stick is given its shape through [[steam bending]]. Holes are drilled in the top portion of the head and the sidewall (''i.e.'', the side of the stick head), permitting weaving of string, which is then hardened by dipping the in [[resin]]. [[Leather]] "runners" are strung from the top of the "head" to the "throat" of the stick. Then nylon string is woven in to create the pocket.<ref name="stickmaker">{{cite web|title=The Stick Maker|url=http://redhawkslax.com/history/the-stick-maker/|publisher=Onondaga Redhawks}}</ref> [[File:Stick Diagram.png|right|thumbnail|Diagram of Mitchell Brothers wooden lacrosse goalie stick.]] The wooden lacrosse stick dates back to the creation of the sport and is still made by craftsmen around the world. Though modern lacrosse sticks made of plastic have become the overwhelming choice for contemporary lacrosse players, traditional wooden lacrosse sticks are still commonly used by [[Goaltender (box lacrosse)|box lacrosse goaltenders]], senior and masters players, and by women's [[field lacrosse]] players. Wooden sticks are still legal under [[Canadian Lacrosse Association]] and NCAA rules but are subject to the same size regulations as modern lacrosse sticks. The only exception to this is the [[Western Lacrosse Association]], which prohibited the use of wooden sticks by non-goaltenders some years ago. The last WLA player to use one was A.J. Smith of the [[Coquitlam Adanacs]], c. 2003–04, who had been [[grandfathered]].
==Men's modern stick== ===Head=== [[Image:lacrosse head diagram.jpg|thumb|left|Diagram of a Men's Lacrosse Stick Head]] In 1970, the first patent (US Patent #3,507,495) for a synthetic lacrosse stick was issued to [[STX (sports manufacturer)|STX]].<ref>{{cite web|title= US Pat #3,507,495 'Lacrosse Stick' Tucker et al|url=http://www.prior-ip.com/patent/2614716/lacrosse-stick?q=BURNETT%20&%20CO%20WM%20T}}</ref> A modern lacrosse stick consists of a plastic molded head attached to a metal shaft. The head is strung with nylon or leather strings to form a pocket. The dimensions of the stick (length, width, sidewall height, and depth of the pocket) are governed by league rules, such as [[NCAA]] rules for collegiate players or [[Federation of International Lacrosse|FIL]] rules for international players.
[[File:Lacrosse stick 8028.jpg|thumb|Field goalie's stick.]] In men's lacrosse, the head of the stick must be {{convert|6|to|10|in|cm}} wide at its widest point under [[NCAA]] rules. Most stick are the minimum 6 inches wide. The head of the [[Goaltender (field lacrosse)|goalie]]'s stick is much larger and must be between 10 to 12 inches wide under NCAA rules or up to 15 inches wide under FIL rules.<ref name="ncaa17rules">{{cite web|title=Men's Lacrosse 2017 and 2018 Rules|url=http://www.ncaapublications.com/productdownloads/LC18.pdf|publisher=NCAA}}</ref>{{rp|page=14}}<ref name="fil17rules">{{cite web|title=2017-2018 Rules of Men’s Field Lacrosse|url=https://filacrosse.com/wp-content/downloads/men/Rules/FIL_MF_Rulebook_2017-2018-A4v1-1.pdf|publisher=Federation of International Lacrosse}}</ref>{{rp|page=7}} The sidewalls of the head may not be more than two inches tall.
===Pocket=== The pocket of the head is where the ball is carried and caught. It consists of interwoven string attached to the head. Traditional stringing with leather strings interwoven with nylon has declined in popularity in favor of synthetic mesh stringing. Mesh is typically made of nylon and comes in a variety of diamond configurations, which can affect the pocket's throwing and retention characteristics.
The typical mesh pocket uses four main nylon strings to affix the mesh piece to the head: a topstring, two sidewalls, and a bottom string. The topstring is often made of a slightly thicker string, in order to resist the abrasive forces that come from scooping the ball up. The sidewalls are used to affix individual mesh diamonds to the sidewall holes on the sidewall of the head. The sidewalls have the most effect on the pocket's performance, as they dictate the placement of the pocket in the head, the tightness of the channel of the pocket, and even the pocket depth. The bottom string is used to fine-tune the pocket depth, and serves to keep the ball from slipping through the bottom of the pocket.
[[File:Lacrosse head.jpg|thumb|right|A legal men's pocket where the top of the ball is above the bottom of the stick's sidewall.]]
In addition to the four strings used to affix the mesh piece, shooting strings are woven through the diamonds of the mesh in order to help fine-tune the pocket's characteristics. They can either be made of typical nylon string, or a hockey style lace. Shooting strings are often used in straight, U, or V shapes. They serve to increase the pocket's hold on the ball, as well as fine-tune the way the stick throws. They can act to change the tension of various portions of the pocket, helping to create a "ramp" for the ball to roll along as it exits the pocket.
As of the 2013 season, the NCAA has passed a rule stating that shooting strings are limited to an area within a 4-inch arc drawn from the top of the plastic of the scoop.This essentially eliminates U- or V-shaped shooting strings, as they almost always cross below the 4-inch line. The pocket depth is governed by rule as well. When the ball is placed in the deepest point, the top of the ball must not be below the bottom of the sidewall.<ref name=ncaa17rules />{{rp|page=15}}
===Shaft=== Modern handles, more commonly referred to as "shafts," are made of hollow metal. They are usually octagonal, instead of round, in order to provide a better grip. Most are made of [[aluminum]], [[titanium]], [[scandium]], or alloys, but some shafts are still made from other materials, including wood, plastic, or [[fiberglass]]. The open end of the hollow shaft must be covered with tape or a plug (commonly referred to as the "butt" or "butt end" of the stick), usually made of rubber. The head of the stick is usually attached to the shaft with a screw to keep it in place.
Stick length is governed by NCAA regulations, which require that men's sticks (including the head) be from 40 to 42 inches long for offensive players, 52 to 72 inches long for defensemen, and 40 to 72 inches long for goalies.<ref name=equipment>{{cite web |url=https://www.uslacrosse.org/safety/equipment/player-equipment |title=Player Equipment |publisher=US Lacrosse}}</ref> Offensive players usually prefer their sticks to be the minimum length (40 inches) in order to give them the advantage of having a shorter stick to protect from defensive checks. Conversely, defensive players usually prefer their sticks to be the maximum length (72 inches) to permit them the greatest range in covering their offensive player.
In 2016, a rules clarification was made by the NCAA Men’s Lacrosse Rules Committee. Questions have arisen regarding the alteration of the shaft circumference. The circumference of the shaft cannot exceed 3 1/2". To be clear, added tape to the shaft must not make the shaft exceed this circumference measurement.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ncaa.org/sites/default/files/2016DIMLA_MEMO_2.2.16_Interpretations_and_Clarifications_020516.pdf|title = 2016 Rules Updates and Clarifications|date = February 4, 2016|access-date = |website = NCAA|publisher = NCAA|last = Scalise|first = Bob}}</ref>
[[Image:warrior diamonds.jpg|center|frame|Three offensive-player length shafts for men's lacrosse]]
==Women's modern stick== In women's lacrosse, the stick dimensions are similar except the pocket depth is much shallower. NCAA rules dictate that the head of a woman's stick may be from seven to nine inches wide, and must be strung traditionally, with a pocket formed by a grid of leather strings. Nylon mesh stringing, permitted in men's sticks, is not permitted in women's sticks; however, the goalkeeper's stick head may be up to 12 inches wide and is allowed to be strung with nylon mesh. The legal depth of a women's stick pocket is determined by the following test: the top of the lacrosse ball, when placed in the pocket, must remain above the top edge of the sidewall. Women's sticks can be 35.5 to 43.25 inches long.<ref name=womenequipment>{{cite web |url=https://www.uslacrosse.org/safety/equipment/player-equipment#women |title=Equipment for Girls' and Women's Lacrosse |publisher=US Lacrosse}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [https://www.uslacrosse.org/rules/mens-rules Men's lacrosse rules] * [https://www.uslacrosse.org/rules/womens-rules Women's lacrosse rules] * [https://www.uslacrosse.org/rules/boys-rules Boys' lacrosse rules] * [https://www.uslacrosse.org/rules/girls-rules Girls' lacrosse rules]
