revision.text:
'''Long slow distance''' ('''LSD''') is a form of [[Aerobic exercise|aerobic]] [[endurance training]] in [[running]] and [[cycling]].<ref name=sportsfitness>http://www.sport-fitness-advisor.com/aerobic-endurance-training.html</ref><ref name="Burke">Burke, Ed and Ed Pavalka. 2000. ''The complete book of long-distance cycling: build the strength, skills, and confidence to ride as far as you want.'' [[Rodale, Inc.|Rodale]] {{ISBN|1-57954-199-2}}.</ref> Physiological adaptations to LSD training include improved [[cardiovascular]] function, improved [[thermoregulation|thermoregulatory]] function, improved [[Mitochondrion|mitochondrial]] [[Portal:Metabolism|energy production]], increased oxidative capacity of [[skeletal muscle]], and increased utilization of fat for fuel.<ref name=sportsfitness/> [[Ernst van Aaken]], a German physician and coach, is generally recognized as the founder of the long slow distance method of endurance training.<ref name="Morris">Morris, Alfred F. 1984. ''Sports medicine: prevention of athletic injuries.'' [[University of Michigan]] {{ISBN|0-697-00087-7}}</ref><ref name="Anderson">Anderson, Bob and Joe Henderson. 1972. ''Guide to distance running.'' [[Indiana University]].</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Kenney |first1=W. Larry |last2=Wilmore |first2=Jack H. |last3=Costill |first3=David L. |title=Physiology of Sport and Exercise |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YHZtv4XKeCMC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=April 24, 2012 |edition=5th |series= |volume= |date= May 2011 |origyear=1994 |publisher=Human Kinetics |location=Champaign, Illinois |isbn=978-0-7360-9409-2 |pages=222–223 |chapter=Principles of Exercise Training |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=YHZtv4XKeCMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA222#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Long slow distance training is a form of [[continuous training]] performed at a constant pace of low to moderate intensity over an extended distance or duration.<ref name="Gamble">{{cite book |last1=Gamble |first1=Paul |authorlink1= |title=Strength and Conditioning for Team Sports: Sport-Specific Physical Preparation for High Performance |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qNBikBqCtU0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=April 25, 2012 |year=2010 |publisher=Routledge / Taylor & Francis |location=New York |isbn=978-0-415-49626-1 |pages=67–68 |chapter=Metabolic conditioning for team sports |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=qNBikBqCtU0C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA67#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The moderate training intensity of LSD is effective in improving endurance and [[VO2 max|maximum oxygen uptake]] in individuals who are undertrained or moderately trained.<ref name="Gamble"/> Long slow distance training is thought not to be effective when used in isolation by well-trained athletes, who in order to achieve further improvements in metabolic conditioning require higher training intensities that are not sustainable at the work durations associated with LSD.<ref name="Gamble"/>
==History== [[Tim Noakes]], a professor of exercise and sports science at the [[University of Cape Town]], suggests that it was [[Arthur F. H. Newton|Arthur Newton]] who initially proposed that running longer distances at slower paces was the most effective training method for beginning runners.<ref name="Noakes">{{cite book |last1=Noakes |first1=Tim |authorlink1=Tim Noakes |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=The Lore of Running |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wAa9qq9kbncC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition=4th |series= |volume= |year=2003 |origyear= |publisher=Human Kinetics |location= |language= |isbn= 978-0-87322-959-3 |oclc= |doi= |page= |pages=278, 286–289 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=Developing a Training Foundation |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=wAa9qq9kbncC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA258#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> Noakes asserts that after this method was rediscovered in the 1960s, [[Joe Henderson (runner)|Joe Henderson]] coined the term "long slow distance".<ref name="Noakes"/>
==Joe Henderson== Long slow distance running was promoted as a training method by [[Joe Henderson (runner)|Joe Henderson]] in 1969.<ref name="Henderson">{{cite book |last=Henderson|first= Joe|authorlink= Joe Henderson (runner)|title= Long, Slow Distance|year= 1969|publisher= Tafnews Press |location= Mountain View CA 94040}}</ref> Henderson saw his approach as providing an alternative to the dominant school of training for distance running which he called “PTA school of running – the pain, torture, and agony” approach. He documented the success of six competitive runners who followed in one form or another an LSD training regime, sometimes combining a few more strenuous workouts with the regular long slow distance running with weekly mileages ranging from 50-60 to 120–150 miles per week, with marathon personal bests between 2:14 and 2:50 hours.<ref name="Henderson" /> In addition, there are ultra-marathoners who use a similar method for training.<ref>{{cite journal|title=A Slow Train to Fitness|journal=Outside Magazine|date=April 1996|first=Mark|last=Jannot|volume=|issue=|pages=|url=http://outside.away.com/outside/magazine/0496/9604bsft.html|accessdate=2007-05-25}}</ref> A typical 5k runner might consider 8 to 10 miles of LSD, while a marathoner might run 20 or more miles. LSD runs are typically done at an easy pace, 1–3 minutes per mile slower than a runner's 10k pace. The objectives of these runs are to build blood volume and to increase muscle strength, endurance, and aerobic fitness.
Henderson’s book was not only directed at competitive runners, but also at runners who wanted to have fun running. He writes, “LSD isn't just a training method. It's a whole way of looking at the sport. Those who employ it are saying running is fun – all running, not just the competitive part which yields rewards.” <ref>{{cite book |last=Henderson|title= Long, Slow Distance|year=1969}} [http://www.joehenderson.com/lsdbook/ Original Introduction]</ref><ref>Henderson would later write that he stopped using LSD as "misleading term" shortly after the publication of ''Long Slow Distance''. (see: Henderson, Joe. ''Marathon Training'' (2003), 2nd edition, Human Kinetics, {{ISBN|978-0736051910}}, p. 36</ref>
==Approaches to running== During the [[running boom of the 1970s]], many recreational runners used LSD as a basis for training.<ref>{{cite book |last= Glover|author2=Shepherd|title= The Runner’s Handbook|year= 1978}}p.1</ref> One of the "fathers" of the [[Honolulu Marathon]], cardiologist [[Jack Scaff]] used a long slow distance approach to train runners in his marathon clinics.<ref>{{cite book |last=Osman |first=Mark Hazard|authorlink= |title= The Honolulu Marathon|year=2006|publisher=Lulu.com |location=|isbn=0-9673079-2-9 }}[https://books.google.com/books?id=QZkG5BMoEWcC&printsec=frontcover The Honolulu Marathon]</ref><ref>http://www.honolulumarathon.org/?s=halloffame</ref> Scaff advised his runners to follow the "talk test", an idea that had originated from Lydiard in which runners should be going slow enough to be able to hold a conversation.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The rules of the road|journal=Sports Illustrated|date= 27 February 1978|first=Kenny|last=Moore|volume=|issue=|url=|format=|pages=62}}[http://cnnsi.printthis.clickability.com/pt/cpt?action=cpt&title=Jack+Scaff+Honolulu+Duncan+MacDonald+Willy+Williamson+Hawaii+Waikiki+Jeff+Wells+-+SI+Vault&expire=&urlID=27497636&fb=Y&url=http%3A%2F%2Fvault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com%2Fvault%2Farticle%2Fmagazine%2FMAG1093368%2Findex.htm&partnerID=289881]</ref> According to sportswriter John Brant in his 2006 book ''[[Duel in the Sun (book)|Duel in the Sun]]'', almost every serious distance runner in the early 1980s used Lydiard's system of building an endurance base with many miles at an [[Aerobic exercise|aerobic pace]] before running shorter distances at an [[anaerobic exercise|anaerobic pace]].<ref name="Brant 2006 62">{{cite book|last=Brant|first=John|title=Duel In The Sun: Alberto Salazar, Dick Beardsley, and America's greatest marathon|publisher=Rodale|year=2006|pages=62|isbn=1-59486-262-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RCxj_PUyvycC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Duel+in+the+Sun&cd=2#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Starting out with an hour run, three times a week, and building up to weekly averages of 40 to 60 miles a week for the last three months, thousands of graduates of the program have found that they could complete the full [[Honolulu Marathon]] which is held every year in beginning of December. The clinic’s approach can be seen from its original Rules of the Road, now referred to as the "basic set of rules that lay the foundation for your training."<ref>{{cite book |last=Scaff Jr |first=Jack |authorlink= |title= Your First Marathon: The Last Word in Long-Distance Running|year=2011|publisher=Belknap Publishing & Design, LLC |location=Honolulu, Hawaii |isbn=978-0-9816403-1-0 }}p. 4</ref> :The rules: :*No fewer than three runs per week :*No more than five runs per week :*No less than one hour per run :*No farther than 15 miles on any run :*One run per week lasting two hours or more (after month 5)<ref>The Honolulu Marathon Clinic offers a shorter form of the rules: :*Train for at least an hour, three times a week. :*Train no more than four times a week. :*Pass the "talk" test while training. :*Drink water every 20 minutes [http://honolulumarathonclinic.org/rules-of-the-road/ HMC]</ref>
A variant of the LSD approach is to combine running slowly with walking breaks. :"It has been found that average runners will have more success if they take regular walk breaks. :"The strategy is unusual in that it doesn't involve simply walking when you are tired. Walk-break runners force themselves to stop even at the beginning of a run when they are fresh." <ref>[http://waddleon.com/HTML/media_WALLSTREET.shtml Parker-Pope, Tara; ''This Jogging Method Turns Out-of-Shape Into Runners'' Wall Street Journal, 25 May 2007. Access date: 2007-05-25]</ref>
An example of such an approach is provided by the running clinics organized by [[Jeff Galloway]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jeffgalloway.com/training/walk_breaks.html |title=Running Injury Free with Jeff Galloway |accessdate=2007-05-25 |last=Galloway |first=Jeff |date=2001-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070521025439/http://www.jeffgalloway.com/training/walk_breaks.html |archivedate=2007-05-21 |df= }}</ref> In running circles, [[John Bingham (runner)|John Bingham]] aka the Penguin, is a well-known practitioner of LSD combined with walking breaks.<ref>[http://www.johnbingham.com/ John Bingham], retrieved 2007-05-25</ref>
==Limitations== Arthur Lydiard wrote that LSD system of training does not reach the levels of effort most effective for building aerobic fitness.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Lydiard |first1=Arthur |authorlink1=Arthur Lydiard |last2=Gilmour |first2=Garth |authorlink2= |title=Running With Lydiard |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aBdgRAn_w_0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=April 25, 2012 |type= |edition=2nd |series= |volume= |year=2007 |origyear=2000 |publisher=Meyer & Meyer Sport |location=Oxford |isbn=978-1-84126-026-6 |page=15 |chapter=The Physiology of Exercise |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=aBdgRAn_w_0C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> [[Pete Pfitzinger]] has written that the long slow distance method of training is acceptable for novice runners hoping to complete a marathon, but that more experienced runners benefit from long runs that, depending on the workout, incorporate a variety of paces including speeds approaching race pace.<ref name="Pfitzinger">{{cite journal |last=Pfitzinger |first=Pete |authorlink=Pete Pfitzinger |date=January–February 2007 |title=The Pfitzinger Lab Report |journal=Running Times |volume= |series= |issue=343 |page=14 |publisher=Rodale, Inc. |issn=0147-2968 |accessdate=April 24, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C8YDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA14#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> According to Pfitzinger, varying paces are necessary because different physiological adaptations, including increased glycogen storage and fat utilization, occur at specific training paces.<ref name="Pfitzinger"/>
Galloway points out that if a runner wishes to increase their speed, [[interval training]] or [[high-intensity interval training|speed training]] is recommended.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Galloway |first1=Jeff |authorlink1=Jeff Galloway |title=Galloway's Book on Running |year=1984 |publisher=Shelter Publications |isbn=978-0-936070-03-2 |page=58}}</ref> Henderson uses races as speedwork and is a proponent of speedwork in limited quantities.
The scientific literature indicates that high-intensity training can provide greater benefit towards anaerobic capacity than moderate-intensity endurance training.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 8897392 | volume=28 | title=Effects of moderate-intensity endurance and high-intensity intermittent training on anaerobic capacity and VO2max | date=October 1996 | journal=Med Sci Sports Exerc | pages=1327–30 | last1 = Tabata | first1 = I | last2 = Nishimura | first2 = K | last3 = Kouzaki | first3 = M | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al | doi=10.1097/00005768-199610000-00018}}</ref> The U.S. Army is reducing the use of long runs in its physical training programs.<ref>[http://www.army.mil/-news/2007/02/26/1986-military-playing-down-long-runs-adopting-more-diverse-fitness-programs/ Military Playing Down Long Runs, Adopting More Diverse Fitness Programs]</ref>
==See also== * [[Continuous training]] * [[High-intensity interval training]] * [[Interval training]] * [[Strength training]] * [[vVO2max|vVO<sub>2</sub>max]]
==References== {{citation style|date=March 2013}}
* {{cite book |last= Glover|first= Robert|authorlink=|author2= Jack Shepherd|title= The Runner’s Handbook|year= 1978|publisher= [[Penguin Books]]|location= New York|isbn= 0-14-046325-9|page= 1}} * {{cite book |last=Henderson|first= Joe|authorlink= Joe Henderson (runner)|title= Long, Slow Distance|year= 1969|publisher= Tafnews Press |location= Mountain View, CA 94040}} * {{cite journal | quotes = | author = Moore, Kenny | title = Honolulu Marathon Clinic | journal = Sports Illustrated | date = 27 February 1978 | volume = | issue = | pages =60–68 | accessdate = 2008-03-31}}[http://cnnsi.printthis.clickability.com/pt/cpt?action=cpt&title=Jack+Scaff+Honolulu+Duncan+MacDonald+Willy+Williamson+Hawaii+Waikiki+Jeff+Wells+-+SI+Vault&expire=&urlID=27497636&fb=Y&url=http%3A%2F%2Fvault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com%2Fvault%2Farticle%2Fmagazine%2FMAG1093368%2Findex.htm&partnerID=289881] * {{cite book |last=Scaff Jr |first=Jack |authorlink= |title= Your First Marathon: The Last Word in Long-Distance Running|year=2011|publisher=Belknap Publishing & Design, LLC |location=Honolulu, Hawaii |isbn=978-0-9816403-1-0 }} {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.joehenderson.com Joe Henderson] * [http://www.jeffgalloway.com Jeff Galloway] * [http://www.johnbingham.com/ John Bingham (The Penguin)] * [http://honolulumarathonclinic.org/ Honolulu Marathon Clinic]
[[Category:Aerobic exercise]] [[Category:Endurance games]] [[Category:Running]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Mark Robinson |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|12|25}} |birth_place = [[Bendigo]], Australia |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[Melbourne]], Australia |nationality = |other_names = "Robbo"<ref name="Herald Sun Profile">{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/about-mark-robinson/story-fni5f0at-1226692169013 |title=Mark Robinson – Man of the people |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1 February 2013 |website=www.heraldsun.com.au |publisher=News Corp Australia|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref> |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = [[Herald Sun|News Corp Australia]], [[1116 SEN]], [[Fox Footy]] |occupation = Journalist |home_town = |title = Chief football writer |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Mark Robinson''' (born 25 December 1967) is an Australian sports journalist. He is the chief football writer for [[Melbourne]]'s ''[[Herald Sun]]'' newspaper, appears on the [[1116 SEN]] radio station's pre-match [[Australian Football League]] (AFL) discussion and co-hosts [[Fox Footy]]'s ''[[AFL 360]]'' television program.
==Career== A junior footballer for the [[Sandhurst Football Club]] in Bendigo, Robinson began covering football in 1992. Throughout his career he has predominantly covered [[Australian rules football]] and has been the chief football writer for the ''[[Herald Sun]]'' since 2012 following the retirement of [[Mike Sheahan]].<ref name="Herald Sun Chief Football Writer Appointment">{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/afl/mark-robinson-heads-up-your-no1-footy-team-as-herald-sun-leads-the-way-in-afl-coverage/story-fnelctok-1226526117905 |title=Mark Robinson heads up your No.1 footy team as Herald Sun leads the way in AFL coverage |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=29 November 2012 |website=www.news.com.au |publisher=News Corp Australia |accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref>
Robinson has co-hosted the ''[[AFL 360]]'' television program on [[Fox Footy]] since 2010.
Robinson was a panelist on many of the [[1116 SEN]] radio station's shows, including ''The Run Home'' and match day AFL discussion until the end of the 2017 season
In 2018, Robinson joined 3AW as a panelist on the Sunday Sport show alongside Daniel Harford and Jimmy Bartel.
==Controversies and feuds== Robinson has been rumoured to have been involved in a variety of verbal and physical altercations with several fellow journalists, including [[Damian Barrett]],<ref name="Barrett Feud">{{cite web |url=http://www.triplem.com.au/melbourne/sport/afl/news/2014/8/damian-barrett-responds-to-a-whack-from-mark-robinson |title=Purple vs. Robbo |accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref> [[Andy Maher]]<ref name="Maher Feud">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NfzRJMtdbkE |title=AFL 360 (Mar 6th) – Andy Maher is a wanker |accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref> and [[Michael Warner (journalist)|Michael Warner]].<ref name="Warner Feud">{{cite web |url=http://www.humanheadline.com.au/Hinch-Says/People-In-Glasshouses |title=People in Glasshouses |accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Born and raised in Bendigo, Robinson resides in Melbourne with his pet dogs Elvis and Tiger.

{{for|the North Korean festival commonly known as the "Mass Games"|Arirang Festival}} [[File:Bundesturnfest Milwaukee 1893.jpg|thumb|Federal Gymnastics Festival in Milwaukee, 1893.]] [[File:Slet1920.jpg|thumb|Czech [[Sokol]] festival, Prague, 1920.]] [[File:Card Stunt for Park Chung-hee.jpg|thumb|Honoring [[South Korean President]] [[Park Chung-hee]] in a [[South Korean Army]] Parade at Armed Forces day on October 1, 1973.]] [[Image:North Korea mass games 1998.jpg|thumb|right|1998 mass games in [[Pyongyang]]. The performers are honouring the image of the former [[North Korea]]n leader [[Kim Il-sung|Kim Il Sung]].]] [[Image:North korea mass games.jpg|thumb|[[Arirang Festival]] mass games display in Pyongyang.]] [[File:All hail Kim Il-sung.jpg|thumb|right|Mass games festival in North Korea. The performers are honouring the image of the former [[North Korea]]n leader [[Kim Il-sung]].]] '''Mass games''' or '''mass gymnastics''' are a form of [[performing arts]] or [[gymnastics]] in which large numbers of performers take part in a highly regimented performance that emphasizes group dynamics rather than individual prowess.
==North Korea== Mass games are now performed only in the [[Rungrado May Day Stadium]] (the [[List of stadiums by capacity|highest capacity stadium in the world]]) but in the '90s there were mass games held at the [[Kim Il-sung Stadium]]. Mass Games can basically be described as a synchronized [[socialist realism|socialist-realist]] spectacular, featuring over 100,000 participants in a 90-minute display of gymnastics, dance, acrobatics, and dramatic performance, accompanied by music and other effects, all wrapped in a highly politicized package. Students practiced every day from January onwards. The 90 minute performance is held every evening at 7pm and features the 'largest picture in the world' a giant mosaic of individual students each holding a book whose pages links with their neighbours’ to make up one gigantic scene. When the students turn the pages the scene or individual elements of the scene change, up to 170 pages make up one book.
According to [[Kim Jong-il]], the philosophy behind the events was that:
{{quote|Developing mass gymnastics is important in training schoolchildren to be fully developed communist people. To be a fully developed communist man, one must acquire a revolutionary ideology, the knowledge of many fields, rich cultural attainments and a healthy and strong physique. These are the basic qualities required of a man of the communist type. Mass gymnastics play an important role in training schoolchildren to acquire these communist qualities. Mass gymnastics foster particularly healthy and strong physiques, a high degree of organization, discipline and collectivism in schoolchildren. The schoolchildren, conscious that a single slip in their action may spoil their mass gymnastic performance, make every effort to subordinate all their thoughts and actions to the collective.|Kim Jong-il, ''On Further Developing Mass Gymnastics: Talk to mass Gymnastics Producers. April 11th 1987''<ref>{{cite book|author=Kim Jong-il|title=On Further Developing Mass Gymnastics: Talk to Mass Gymnastics Producers April 11, 1987|url=https://www.korea-dpr.com/lib/Kim%20Jong%20Il%20-%205/ON%20FURTHER%20DEVELOPING%20MASS%20GYMNASTICS.pdf|year=1987|publisher=Foreign Languages Publishing House|location=Pyongyang|page=1}}</ref>}}
==Outside North Korea== ===Guyana=== Guyana under the leader [[Forbes Burnham]] held mass games. They were first held in February 1980 to commemorate the founding of the [[Co-operative Republic of Guyana]] <ref>https://apjjf.org/2015/13/4/Moe-Taylor/4258.html</ref> ===Europe=== In Germany, [[Friedrich Ludwig Jahn]] developed an efficient gymnastics method called Massenturnen. For propagating Massenturnen, Germany started Massenturnen show ([[:de:Deutsches Turnfest]]).
Mass games developed alongside 19th century [[nationalism|nationalist]] movements, particularly the Czech [[Sokol]] movement.
In [[Romania]], the [[Communist Romania|communist government]] organized compulsory mass games after [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party]] leader [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]] and [[Elena Ceaușescu|his wife]] had visited the [[People's Republic of China]] and saw such games there. These were the hardest working days of the year since every individual was required to participate along with his fellow workers. Being late on this day or not shouting the party leader's name loudly enough would lead to being reported by fellow workers to prosecutors.
In [[Bulgaria]], mass games were occasionally held during the ''Zname na mira'' ("Flag of Peace") international youth festivals. However, Bulgaria did not have a tradition of mass games, and performances were rare.
===Other=== In [[Japan]], schools adopted German gymnastics and mass games were started. Since 1925, mass games were played in Meiji Jingū Kyōgi Taikai (Meiji Shrine Sports Competition).
==Current performances==
Today, mass games are regularly performed only in [[North Korea]], where they take place to celebrate national holidays such as the birthdays of former rulers [[Kim Il-sung]] and [[Kim Jong-il]]. In recent years, they have been the main attraction of the [[Arirang Festival]] in Pyongyang. The 2004 documentary film by VeryMuchSo Productions and Koryo Tours ''[[A State of Mind]]'' details the training of two young girls from Pyongyang who perform in the mass games.
Arirang mass games were first performed in 2002 in Pyongyang's May Day Stadium and have been held every year since – between August and October and on one occasion in Spring. The show was on 4 times a week. Tourists from all over the World were welcomed to the DPRK during Mass Games.
[[Sokol]] organization for [[Czech Republic|Czech]] and other. [[Eastern Europe]]an youth athletic organize exposition, competition, and nationalist identity building event organized called '''Slet'''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sokolusachicago.com/History.html |title=History |accessdate=22 December 2008 |publisher=SOKOL USA CHICAGO GYMNASTICS}}</ref> The word ''slet'' means 'a gathering of falcons'. The first Sokol slet was held in 1882 in [[Prague]] to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the founding of the Sokol organization.<ref>Bednar, Charles and Sivak, Paul: ''The Sokols and Their Endeavor''. 1948.</ref> Since 1994 it is held every six years.
It is also possible to consider the opening ceremonies of the Olympic Games as instances of mass games.

revision.comment: /* External links */ remove links not specifically about article subject per [[WP:EL]]. Other Ski museums are not in the context of this article, the Ski association is not what this article is about. This isn't a place to hang links off.
revision.text:
{{Infobox building |name= National Ski Hall of Fame |native_name= |native_name_lang= |former_names= |alternate_names= |status= |image= National Ski Hall of Fame - side.JPG |image_alt= |caption= Side view of building shows its [[ski jump]] shape |map_type= Michigan |map_alt= |map_caption= |altitude= |building_type= |architectural_style= |structural_system= |cost= |ren_cost= |client= |owner= |current_tenants= |landlord= |location= |address= |location_town= |location_country= |coordinates = {{coord|46.503|-87.6655|display=inline,title}} |groundbreaking_date= |start_date= |completion_date= |opened_date= |inauguration_date= |renovation_date= |demolition_date= |destruction_date= |height= |diameter= |antenna_spire= |roof= |top_floor= |other_dimensions= |floor_count= |floor_area= |seating_type= |seating_capacity= |elevator_count= |main_contractor= |architect= |architecture_firm= |structural_engineer= |services_engineer= |civil_engineer= |other_designers= |quantity_surveyor= |awards= |designations= |ren_architect= |ren_firm= |ren_str_engineer= |ren_serv_engineer= |ren_civ_engineer= |ren_oth_designers= |ren_qty_surveyor= |ren_awards= |url= {{URL|http://www.skihall.com/}} |embedded= |references= }} The '''U.S. Ski and Snowboard Hall of Fame and Museum''' is located in [[Ishpeming, Michigan]], the birthplace of organized [[skiing]] in the [[United States]]. Located in the state's [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan|Upper Peninsula]], the building includes the hall of fame and museum, as well as a theater, library, gift shop, offices, and ample storage space for archive material and collections. The current building opened in 1992.
==History== [[File:National Ski Hall of Fame - front.JPG|thumb|Front view of building]] The National Ski Association, today known as the [[U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association]], was formed in Ishpeming in 1905, {{Years or months ago|1905}}.<ref name="News">{{cite news |url=http://apps.detnews.com/apps/history/index.php?id=149 |title=Michigan's long history of ski jumping |first1=Vivian M. |last1=Baulch |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=February 1, 2002 |issn=1055-2715 |accessdate=February 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121209215028/http://apps.detnews.com/apps/history/index.php?id=149 |archivedate=December 9, 2012 |df= }}</ref> It was formed during a meeting of ski clubs from Ishpeming, [[Minneapolis]], [[Red Wing, Minnesota]], and [[Eau Claire, Wisconsin]].<ref name="News"/> Ispheming Ski Club founder [[Carl Tellefsen]] (1854−1908) was its first president,<ref name=istohoms>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3C4xAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9hAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7706%2C782524 |newspaper=Milwaukee Sentinel |title=Ishpeming to host top ski officials |date=February 12, 1961 |page=4-S }}</ref><ref name=htaoshk>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=x1YaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4icEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7174%2C499332 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |last=Dooley |first=Don |title=Hall traces art of skiing |date=February 12, 1967 |page=3, part 4 }}</ref> and for his contribution, he was among the first four to be accorded honored membership in the hall of fame in early 1957.<ref name=nsfpofto>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=megVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PRAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7105%2C1087406 |newspaper=Milwaukee Sentinel |title=Name ski fame picks on Feb. 21 |date=February 13, 1958 |page=8, part 3}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author= Staff |url= http://medals.ussa.org/magnoliaPublic/ussa/en/about/history.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090412205624/http://medals.ussa.org/magnoliaPublic/ussa/en/about/history.html |archivedate= April 12, 2009 |title= USSA History |publisher= U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association |year= 2007 |accessdate= June 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=3lgEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA41&ots=W5f78vTJAw&dq=%22Carl%20Tellefsen%22&pg=PA41#v=onepage&q=%22Carl%20Tellefsen%22&f=false |title= Forefather: Carl Tellefsen |first1= Alice |last1= Johnson |first2= Mary |last2= Morissette |journal= Skiing Heritage Journal |date=June 2002 |volume= 14 |issue= 2 |page= 41}}</ref>
The Roland Palmedo Memorial Library, one of the largest research ski libraries in the United States is housed here. [[Roland Palmedo]] (1895−1977) was a ski-sport builder and contributor for more than 50 years.<ref name=taminrp>{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qIfPW3SvGfwC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21#v=onepage&q&f=false |journal=Skiing Heritage |last=Lund |first=Morten |title=The amazing, intriguing Roland Palmedo - ski pioneer |date=September 2009 |pages=21–25}}</ref> He helped to organize the [[National Ski Patrol]],<ref name=nspfyriv>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dJQzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zOkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1043%2C5278646 |newspaper=Palm Beach Daily News |last=Strauss |first=Michael |title=National Ski Patrol plans 50-year reunion in Vermont |date=March 13, 1988 |page=B8}}</ref> the teacher certification program, and various early ski teams and clubs. Palmedo also founded [[Mad River Glen]] ski area, edited two skiing books, and developed one of the most extensive ski libraries in America. Following his death, his family donated his library to the National Ski Hall of Fame and Museum where it has become the nucleus for the Roland Palmedo Memorial Library.
==Notable members of the Hall of Fame== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" |Name ! scope="col" |Inducted |- !scope="row" |[[Charles Minot Dole|Charles "Minnie" Dole]] |1958 |- !scope="row" |[[Roger Langley]] |1958 |- !scope="row" |[[Andrea Mead Lawrence]] |1958 |- !scope="row" |[[Dave McCoy]] |1967 |- !scope="row" |[[Jill Boothe]] |1967 |- !scope="row" |[[Sel Hannah]] |1968 |- !scope="row" |[[Nancy Greene]] |1969 |- !scope="row" |[[Dick Buek]] |1974 |- !scope="row" |[[Tom Corcoran (skier)|Tom Corcoran]] |1978 |- !scope="row" |[[Joan Hannah]] |1978 |- !scope="row" |[[Warren Miller (director)|Warren Miller]] |1978 |- !scope="row" |[[Howard Head]] |1979 |- !scope="row" |[[Bob Beattie (skiing)|Bob Beattie]] |1984<ref name="beattie1984">{{cite web|title=Robert Beattie|url=http://www.skihall.com/index.php?_a=document&doc_id=11&id=30|publisher=National Ski Hall of Fame|accessdate=February 17, 2014}}</ref> |- !scope="row" |[[David J. Bradley, M.D. (author, skier)|David Bradley]] |1985 |- !scope="row" |[[Ernie Blake]] |1987<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Ernie Blake, Ski Resort Owner, 75|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/19/obituaries/ernie-blake-ski-resort-owner-75.html|accessdate=25 November 2015|work=The New York Times|date=January 19, 1989}}</ref> |- !scope="row" |[[Tony Wise]] |1988 |- !scope="row" |[[Bob Lange]] |2000 |- !scope="row" |[[H.William Kirschner]] |2001 |- !scope="row" |[[Tommy Moe]] |2003 |- !scope="row" |[[Picabo Street]] |2004 |- !scope="row" |[[Jonny Moseley]] |2006 |- !scope="row" |[[Everett Kircher]] |2007 |- !scope="row" |[[Cary Adgate]] |2008 |- !scope="row" |[[Glen Plake]] |2010 |- !scope="row" |[[Shane McConkey]] |2010 |- !scope="row" |[[Stein Eriksen]] |2010 |- !scope="row" |[[Daron Rahlves]] |2010 |- !scope="row" |[[Scot Schmidt]] |2014 |}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Old Bailey Stadium | image = | location = 503 South Broad Street
[[Clinton, South Carolina|Clinton, SC]] 29325 | broke_ground = 1927 | opened = September 28, 1928 | closed = | demolished = 2018 | owner = [[Presbyterian College]] | operator = Presbyterian College | surface = Natural Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | general_contractor= | tenants = [[Presbyterian Blue Hose]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1928–2018) | seating_capacity = 3,000 |}} '''Old Bailey Stadium''' was a 3,000-seat [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Clinton, South Carolina]]. It was the former home of [[Presbyterian Blue Hose football|Presbyterian College football]] and, at the time of its demolition, the home for Presbyterian men's and women's lacrosse teams.http://www.gobluehose.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=18100&ATCLID=3668557 The stadium opened before the opening game of the [[1928 college football season|1928 season]], and its first game saw the Blue Hose fall to [[Mercer Bears football|Mercer]], 6–7. It served as the home for PC football until the first two games of the [[2002 NCAA Division II football season|2002 season]]. Its last football game was the 2002 home opener, against [[Charleston Southern Buccaneers football|Charleston Southern]], which PC won 26–6.http://www.gobluehose.com/fls/18100/SPORTS/football/2016/2016PresbyterianFootballMediaDayNotes-Final.pdf?DB_OEM_ID=18100 The stadium was demolished in the spring of 2018 to make room for new senior dorms, which are currently being constructed. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Presbyterian Blue Hose football navbox}} {{coord missing|South Carolina}} [[Category:Sports venues in South Carolina]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Laurens County, South Carolina]] [[Category:Presbyterian College]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:1928 establishments in South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1928]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2018]] {{SouthCarolina-sports-venue-stub}}

Klai Juba | structural engineer = John A. Martin & Associates{{cite web|url=http://southwest.construction.com/projects/03_TopProjectsNevada.pdf|title=Dodge Resource Center|author=|date=|work=construction.com|access-date=December 24, 2016}} | services engineer = JBA Consulting Engineers{{cite web|title=Markets|url=http://www.jbace.com/index.php?/markets/hospitalityCachedYou|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511114151/http://www.jbace.com/index.php?%2Fmarkets%2FhospitalityCachedYou|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 11, 2014|publisher=JBA Consulting Engineers|accessdate=May 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}} | general_contractor = Tiberti Construction[https://web.archive.org/web/20021011142151/http://www.tiberti.com/tib_construct/index.html Tiberti Construction - Orleans Arena] | tenants = [[Las Vegas Wranglers]] ([[ECHL]]) (2003–2014)

[[Las Vegas Legends]] ([[MASL]]) (2012–2016) | seating_capacity = [[Boxing]]: 9,500{{cite web|title=Event Production - Configurations|publisher=OrleansArena.com|url=http://www.orleansarena.com/arena-infomation/event-production|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080122042531/http://www.orleansarena.com/arena-infomation/event-production|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 22, 2008|accessdate=March 25, 2008|df=mdy-all}}
[[Concert]]: 8,921

[[Rodeo]]: 5,736 | website = {{URL|http://www.orleansarena.com}} }} The '''Orleans Arena''' is a 9,500-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Paradise, Nevada]], in the [[Las Vegas Valley]]. It is located at the [[Orleans Hotel and Casino]] and is operated by [[Coast Casinos]], a subsidiary of [[Boyd Gaming Corporation]]. It is an occasional home for the [[UNLV Rebels]] basketball team when the [[Thomas & Mack Center]] is in use. The arena was the home of the [[Las Vegas Wranglers]] [[ice hockey]] team from 2003 to 2014 and the [[Las Vegas Gladiators]] [[arena football]] team in 2007 as well as the [[Las Vegas Sin]] [[Legends Football League|women's football]] team. ==Notable events== * On July 12, 2003, [[Ricardo Mayorga]] retained The Ring [[welterweight]] championship with a majority decision over [[Vernon Forrest]], and [[Zab Judah]] defeated [[Demarcus Corley]] on the undercard.{{cite news |title=Mayorga Holds On to Titles|first=Steve|last=Springer|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jul/13/sports/sp-fite13|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 13, 2003|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} * The first Las Vegas Wranglers game at the Orleans Arena was on October 10, 2003, in which a crowd of 2,817 saw the Wranglers defeat the [[Bakersfield Condors (1998–2015)|Bakersfield Condors]], 4–2, in an exhibition game.{{cite news|title=Wranglers Bring Hockey Back to Las Vegas Tonight|first=Royce|last=Feour|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Oct-10-Fri-2003/sports/22339940.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031022090853/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Oct-10-Fri-2003/sports/22339940.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=October 22, 2003|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|date=October 10, 2003|accessdate=May 27, 2012|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Wranglers Win Exhibition Opener|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Oct-11-Sat-2003/sports/22348712.html|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|date=October 11, 2003|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} * The [[Stanley Cup]] visited Orleans Arena on November 25, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3242571|title=Wranglers weekly update - OurSports Central|author=ECHL|date=November 21, 2005|work=oursportscentral.com|access-date=December 24, 2016}} * In November 2006, the arena began hosting the [[Las Vegas Invitational (basketball)|Las Vegas Invitational]], a pre-season [[college basketball]] tournament. It was the first event of its kind to be held at a venue connected to a casino with a [[sports book]], the Las Vegas (College Basketball) Invitational on November 22–26, 2006.{{cite news |title=New Home Court: College Events Move to Orleans|first=Steve|last=Carp|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jul-27-Thu-2006/sports/8714712.html|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|date=July 27, 2006|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} The [[West Coast Conference]] has held its basketball tournaments for men and women at the venue since 2009, the first Division I conference tournament to do so at that type of venue.{{cite news |title=WCC, Arena Sign Three-Year Extension|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=4348856|work=[[ESPN]]|author=Associated Press|date=July 22, 2009|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} In addition the [[Western Athletic Conference]] held its 2011 men's tournament at Orleans Arena and did again in 2012.{{cite news |title=WAC Enters As WCC Exits at Orleans Arena|first=Steve|last=Carp|url=http://www.lvrj.com/sports/wac-enters-as-wcc-exits-at-orleans-arena-117635758.html|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} *In 2007, the [[Las Vegas Gladiators]] of the [[Arena Football League (1987–2008)|Arena Football League]] moved to the arena from the [[Thomas & Mack Center]]. The move failed to increase community interest and the team moved to [[Cleveland, Ohio]], in 2008. *On March 7, 2007, [[Mikey Way]] of [[My Chemical Romance]] got married to his fiancée [[Alicia Simmons (PAIN)|Alicia Simmons]] in the backstage area. *From February 26–28, 2009, the NIAA State Basketball Championship was held at the Orleans Arena. All classifications (1A-4A) attended and played at this venue. *On August 22, 2009, the [[af2]]'s (arena football) [[ArenaCup]] was played between the [[Spokane Shock]] and the [[Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Pioneers]]. Spokane won the game, 74–27. *On November 26, 2011, the UNLV men's basketball team upset No. 1 ranked North Carolina at the arena.{{cite news |title=Rebels Party Like It’s 1990, Knock Off Top-Ranked North Carolina|first=Ray|last=Brewer|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2011/nov/27/party-it-early-1990s-rebels-knock-top-ranked-north/|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Sun]]|date=November 27, 2011|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} *On February 5, 2012, the arena played host to the LFL Lingerie Bowl IX. Los Angeles defeated Philadelphia 28–6. *Between July and October of 2015 [[Global Force Wrestling]] taped the pilot episodes of its planned TV series ''Amped'' at the arena. *On July 26, 2018, the Orleans Arena hosted the penultimate regular season games for the [[2018 JBA season]]. At 5:00 P.M., the [[Seattle Ballers]] blew out the [[Chicago Ballers]] 134–110, while the [[Los Angeles Ballers]] (led by [[LiAngelo Ball|LiAngelo]] and [[LaMelo Ball]]) and the [[Houston Ballers]] (led by Curtis Hollis and Jordon Myers) recorded a high-scoring match at 7:30 P.M. soon afterward, with Los Angeles winning 169–153. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.orleansarena.com}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = Home of the
[[Las Vegas Gladiators]] | years = 2007 | before = [[Thomas & Mack Center]] | after = [[Quicken Loans Arena]] }} {{End}} {{Cleveland Gladiators}} {{LFL Venues}} [[Category:2003 establishments in Nevada]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Paradise, Nevada]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Legends Football League venues]] [[Category:Music venues in the Las Vegas Valley]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Nevada]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Sports venues in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]]

In the sport of [[golf]], a '''penalty''' or '''penalty stroke''' is an additional stroke or strokes added to a player's score for an infraction of the [[rules of golf|rules]]. In [[match play]], rather than adding strokes, the usual penalty is loss of the hole except for penalties assessed for relief from a hazard or a lost ball.
Situations in which a penalty may be assessed include, but are not limited to:
* Declaring your ball unplayable in its current lie. This technically violates one of the primary rules - "Play the ball as it lies", but the rules provide for relief when a ball is in a position where the player does not wish to attempt to play it. Examples include when the ball lies among tree roots or rocks ("between a rock and a hard place"), underneath shrubbery, etc. and attempting to play it would result in damage to the club or the course. A substitute ball is dropped or placed at a penalty of one stroke.<ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule28.html Rules of Golf: Rule 28]</ref> * Hitting the ball into a situation where it cannot be played as it lies even if the player wishes it, such as into a [[water hazard]] (players are allowed to play the ball out of a water hazard without penalty, but it is rarely practical unless the hazard is only a few inches deep), out-of-bounds, or into an area where it becomes lost. A substitute ball is then played at a one-stroke penalty.<ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule27.html#27 Rules of Golf: Rule 27]</ref><ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule26.html#26-2 Rules of Golf: Rule 26-2]</ref> * Hitting the wrong ball, which is any ball other than the ball hit from the tee by that player, or dropped or placed as a substitute or provisional ball. Examples of a wrong ball are another player's ball or an abandoned ball. This is a two-stroke penalty.<ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule15.html#15-3 Rules of Golf: Rule 15-3]</ref> * Picking up your ball, except under certain circumstances such as for identification, to determine if it is cut, split or otherwise unfit for play, to clear the path of another player's ball on the [[putting green]], or to clear loose debris such as leaves or twigs from under or around it. <ref name="Rules of Golf: Rule 18-2">[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule18.html#18-2 Rules of Golf: Rule 18-2]</ref> * Picking up anyone else's ball, except for identification when the location of the ball in question or another in play is uncertain.<ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule18.html#18-3 Rules of Golf: Rule 18-3]</ref> * Interfering with a moving ball; the ball must come to rest completely before it can be addressed again by the player, and players may not deflect or stop a ball in motion by any means. Players who deliberately interfere with any moving ball receive a two-stroke penalty. Incidental, unavoidable contact is generally not penalized, and additional rules determine how the ball must be played (generally as it lies).<ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule19.html#19-2 Rules of Golf: Rule 19-2]</ref><ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule01.html#1-2 Rules of Golf: Rule 1-2]</ref> * Playing a ball out-of-turn or while someone else's ball is in motion. After teeing off, players must play their balls in the order of their distance from the hole. Playing out-of-turn is a one-stroke penalty. The only exception is while on the putting green, when a fellow player's ball obstructs the current player's and the current player wishes the other player to play it rather than lift and mark it. <ref name="Rules of Golf: Rule 18-2"/><ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule22.html#22-2 Rules of Golf: Rule 22-2]</ref> * Cleaning a ball while it is in play, except when the ball is on the green, for identification, or to determine if the ball is unfit for play (a ball is not unfit simply because it is dirty; however a cut or split may be hidden by dirt).<ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule21.html Rules of Golf: Rule 21]</ref> * Equipment violations such as too many clubs (more than 14) in a player's bag or using a ball or club of illegal design. Illegal balls include balls of improper size or weight (less than 1.68" or more than 1.62oz), floating balls, balls with dimples of the wrong size or depth, and "novelty" balls such as exploding or disintegrating balls. In the case of an illegal ball, the player adds two strokes for every hole on which that ball was put in play. Illegal clubs include clubs with a clubhead greater than 460cc, clubs with a concave face, shaft lengths over 48", grips with waisting, bulges or dis-symmetry, etc. In the case of a violation regarding clubs, the player adds two strokes for every hole of the current round played before the violation was discovered. <ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule04.html#4-4 Rules of Golf: Rule 4-4]</ref><ref>[http://www.usga.org/playing/rules/books/rules/rule05.html#5-1 Rules of Golf; Rule 5-1]</ref> When a penalty is incurred because the ball has been lost or hit into an unplayable area, the player plays a new ball or moves the current one according to the rules governing the situation in which the substitution or placement occurs. This may be from the spot at which they hit the ball into that position (a '''stroke and distance penalty'''), a playable point directly in line with the hole and behind its current position, or in some circumstances at a point two clublengths or less and no closer to the hole from which the ball crossed the boundary of the unplayable condition. If the player elects to move an unplayable ball in a [[bunker (golf)|sand trap]], the ball must remain in the hazard.
The penalty stroke assessed is not the stroke made on the new ball; it is counted in addition to any and all swings made at the ball. For instance, hitting a ball into a water hazard, dropping a new ball at the position from which you hit the last one, then hitting the new ball counts as three strokes, not two.
However, under certain circumstances during informal games, especially involving novice players, the penalty stroke is not counted; the player simply drops a ball at the spot of the last hit and plays again. This is an unmitigated violation of several rules of the game which would normally call for disqualification from sanctioned play, but can help make the game more enjoyable in a friendly setting as well as increasing the pace, as it reduces searching for a ball and playing from extremely disadvantageous lies. When an errant shot is re-played from the same spot, it is called a [[mulligan (games)|mulligan]] and neither the first shot nor the penalty stroke is counted.

The club is named after the [[Roland Battalion]], a Ukrainian subunit of the German [[Abwehr]] during [[World War II]]. They are one of the four teams comprising the additional group in the [[Ukraine Rugby Superliga]].

[[Sandys Parish|Sandys]], [[Bermuda]] |capacity |chairman = Marc Bean |coach = [[Marlon Rojas]] (player/coach) |manager = |league = [[Bermudian First Division]] |season = 2015–16 |position = 1st (champions) | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_bluesleevelinesandsides|pattern_ra1=|pattern_so1=|pattern_sh1= | leftarm1=FFFF00|body1=FFFF00|rightarm1=FFFF00|shorts1=0000FF|socks1=0000FF }} '''Somerset Eagles''' is a [[association football|football]] club from [[Sandys Parish|Sandys]], [[Bermuda]]. They play in the [[Bermudian First Division]]. ==History== Eagles have never won the league title and were on the losing side in the [[Bermuda FA Cup]] final twice, in 2010 and 2013.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bermcuphist.html Bermuda – List of Cup Winners] – RSSSF In March 2016 they won the [[Bermudian First Division]] title to win promotion to the [[Bermudian Premier Division]].[http://www.royalgazette.com/soccer/article/20160328/eagles-climb-highest-on-dramatic-final-day Eagles climb highest on dramatic final day] – Royal Gazette They had been in the second tier since their relegation in March 2011.[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20110325/SPORT01/703259959 Eagles will bounce back Rojas] – Royal Gazette ==Historical list of coaches== {{col-begin-small}} * {{flagicon|BER}} Marc Bean[http://www.parliament.bm/Marc_Bean.aspx The Hon. Marc Bean, JP, MP] – Parliament Bermuda * {{flagicon|BER}} Kenny Thompson (- Jul 2010) * {{flagicon|TRI}} [[Marlon Rojas]] (Aug 2010–present)[http://www.socawarriors.net/foreign-based/7516-rojas-appointed-new-coach-of-somerset-eagles.html Rojas appointed new coach of Somerset Eagles] – Soca Warriors {{col-end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bermudafa.com/page/show/2080237-sbrc Club page] – Bermuda FA {{Cingular Wireless Premier Division}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Somerset Eagles}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bermuda]] [[Category:Sandys Parish]] {{Bermuda-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Spot-fixing''' refers to illegal activity in a sport in which a specific aspect of a game, unrelated to the final result but upon which a betting market exists, is fixed in an attempt to ensure a certain result in a [[proposition bet]]; examples include something as minor as timing a no ball or wide delivery in [[cricket]], or timing the first throw-in or corner in association football.
Spot-fixing attempts to defraud bookmakers by a player taking a pre-arranged action to fix the result of that specific event.<ref name="mehaffey">{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE63S1LK20100829 |title=Q+A-Cricket-Spot fixing latest threat to game's integrity | Reuters |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2010 | first=John | last=Mehaffey}}</ref> Spot-fixing differs from [[match fixing]], in which the final result of a match is fixed; or [[point shaving]], in which corrupt players (or officials) attempt to limit the margin of victory of the favoured team. Spot-fixing is more difficult to detect than match fixing or point shaving, and by its nature can be perpetrated by a lone fraudulent player without needing any other players or officials to co-operate. The growth of [[Internet gambling]] and increased variety of betting options (''e.g.'' [[spread betting]], first-scorer betting) resulted in the emergence of spot-fixing, particularly through the first decade of the 2000s.<ref name="Twenty20">{{cite news|last=Selvey |first=Mike |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2010/apr/15/spot-fixing-cricket-mike-selvey |title=Spotting spot-fixing is harder than ever in Twenty20 era | Mike Selvey | Sport |publisher=The Guardian |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=30 August 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
==Examples==
===Association football=== Following his retirement, [[Matt Le Tissier]] admitted that he had bet on the timing of the first throw-in in a match he played for Southampton against Wimbledon in 1995. The plan failed when a teammate who was unaware of the scam managed to keep his underhit pass on the pitch.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson |first=Steve |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/southampton/6130280/Matthew-Le-Tissier-admits-being-part-of-attempted-betting-scam-at-Southampton.html |title=Matthew Le Tissier admits being part of attempted betting scam at Southampton |publisher=Telegraph |date=3 September 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Le Tissier was forced to quickly kick the ball from play to prevent losing money on the bet and managed to "push" after kicking the ball out after 70 seconds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hampshire/8250042.stm |title=UK | England | Hampshire | Le Tissier in police bet inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=11 September 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2010}}</ref> He stated that he felt so silly about the incident that he never attempted it again.
===Cricket=== Spot fixing in cricket first came to international prominence in the [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 2010|2010 Pakistan tour of England]], when it was determined that Pakistani players [[Mohammad Asif]] and [[Mohammad Amir]] intentionally bowled no-balls on specific deliveries as part of a conspiracy involving captain [[Salman Butt]] to defraud bookmakers. As a result, Salman Butt was banned for ten years, Asif for seven years and Amir for five years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/pakistan/7970316/Pakistan-match-fixing-claim-what-is-spot-fixing.html |title=Pakistan match-fixing claim: what is spot-fixing? |publisher=Telegraph |date= 29 August 2010|accessdate=30 August 2010 | location=London}}</ref> The matter became a criminal investigation that resulted in custodial sentences for four people involved; in November 2011, Butt was sentenced to 30 months' imprisonment, with Asif being imprisoned for one year and Amir jailed for six months. {{further|Pakistan cricket spot-fixing controversy}}
In India, [[2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case|five players]] in [[2012_Indian_Premier_League|IPL Season 5 (2012)]] were suspended for spot-fixing. The five players were [[Mohnish Mishra]], [[Shalabh Srivastava]], [[TP Sudhindra]], Harmeet Singh and Abhinav Bali. The suspensions were not for any specific event during the season, but a [[sting operation]] revealed all five either discussing earlier cases of spot-fixing they had been involved in, or seeking future spot-fixing opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|title=BCCI suspends five players accused in spot-fixing|url=http://www.cricketcountry.com/cricket-articles/IPL-2012-BCCI-suspends-five-players-accused-in-spot-fixing/14619|publisher=Cricketcountry.com|accessdate=15 May 2012|author=CricketCountry Staff|date=15 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120519050951/http://www.cricketcountry.com/cricket-articles/IPL-2012-BCCI-suspends-five-players-accused-in-spot-fixing/14619|archivedate=19 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In India, [[2013 Indian Premier League spot-fixing and betting case|three Indian players]] in [[2013_Indian_Premier_League|IPL Season 6 (2013)]] were arrested for spot-fixing: [[Sreesanth]], [[Ankeet Chavan]] and [[Ajit Chandila]]. Along with them, eleven bookmakers were arrested. The Delhi Police arrested the three players in a post-midnight operation in Mumbai on 16 May 2013 for accepting payments of up to Rs. 6 million, for giving away a pre-determined number of runs in an over.<ref>{{cite news|last=DNA Webdesk|title=Sreesanth, 2 other Rajasthan Royals players arrested for spot-fixing, suspended from IPL|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/1835347/report-s-sreesanth-2-other-rajasthan-royals-players-arrested-for-spot-fixing|accessdate=16 May 2013|newspaper=DNA|date=16 May 2013}}</ref> On 13 September, [[Sreesanth]] was given a lifetime ban from the sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/24076409|title=Sreesanth: Former India bowler banned for life for spot-fixing|work=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In England, allegations of spot-fixing were made against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]] bowler [[Mervyn Westfield]], after he bowled poorly in a [[Pro40]] match against Durham in September 2009. Westfield later pleaded guilty to accepting money for spot-fixing in the match, specifically that he attempted to concede twelve runs from his first over (although he conceded only ten);<ref name="convict">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-essex-16527008 | work=BBC News | title=Ex-Essex cricketer Mervyn Westfield admits spot betting charge | date=12 January 2012}}</ref> he was banned for five years and his Essex team-mate and former Pakistan Test bowler [[Danish Kaneria]] received a life ban after he was found to have orchestrated the fix.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Telegraph|publication-place=UK|author=James Rowland|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/9009383/Mervyn-Westfield-spot-fixing-scandal-a-timeline.html|title=Mervyn Westfield spot-fixing scandal: a timeline|date=26 September 2013|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref>
The advent of [[Twenty20|Twenty20 cricket]] is said to have made spot-fixing more difficult to detect in cricket, because the faster and more variable nature of the game makes anomalies related to spot-fixing less visible.<ref name="Twenty20" />
===Rugby league=== Australian [[rugby league]] player [[Ryan Tandy]] was found guilty of spot-fixing during a 2010 [[National Rugby League]] season match between [[North Queensland Cowboys]] and [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]]. Tandy, playing for Canterbury-Bankstown, was involved in spot-fixing the first score of the match to be a North Queensland penalty goal. Observers noted that there had been an unusually high proportion of bets taken on the penalty goal option for the game. Then, in the opening minutes of the game, Tandy was found to have deliberately conceded a [[List of rugby league terms#knock-on|knock-on]] from the match's kick-off and then a penalty for slowing down the play-the-ball in the Cowboys' first attacking set in front of the goalposts, giving North Queensland a chance to kick an easy penalty goal. As it happened, the spot-fixing attempt was unsuccessful, as North Queensland passed up its penalty goal opportunity and scored a try instead. In 2011, Tandy was found guilty of attempting to dishonestly obtain a financial advantage on 6 October 2011, and he received a six-month correction order from the courts and a life ban from rugby league.<ref name=abc-banned>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-04-28/ryan-tandy-dies/5416398?pfm=ms |title=Former NRL player Ryan Tandy found dead from reported drug overdose |work=ABC News (Australia) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Betting controversies in cricket]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spot-Fixing}} [[Category:Association football controversies]] [[Category:Cricket controversies]] [[Category:Match fixing]] [[Category:Sports betting scandals]]

{{For|the former ground of St Mirren F.C. on Love Street, Paisley|Love Street (stadium)}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Simple Digital Arena |nickname = Greenhill Road |image = Greenhill Road - geograph.org.uk - 1160158.jpg |image_size = 275px |caption = View of the Main Stand facade |location = Greenhill Road, [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]] | pushpin_map = Scotland Renfrewshire | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Renfrewshire | pushpin_label_position = left |coordinates = {{coord|55|51|2|N|4|26|38|W|type:landmark|display=inline, intitle}} |broke_ground = 7 January 2008 |opened = 31 January 2009 |surface = Grass |acreage = 12.5 |dimensions = 105m x 68m (115y x 74y) |scoreboard = Yes |owner = [[St Mirren F.C.]] |operator = [[St Mirren F.C.]] |record_attendance = 7,542 - St Mirren v Kilmarnock (31 January 2009) |construction_cost = £8 million |architect = [[Barr Construction]] |main_contractors = [[Barr Construction]] |publictransit = [[Paisley St James railway station|St James Railway Station &]] [[Paisley Gilmour Street station|Gilmour Street Station]] |tenants = [[St Mirren F.C.]] (2009–)
[[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland under-21]] (2011–) |seating_capacity = {{SPFL-stadiums|mirren}} }} '''St Mirren Park''', also known as ''' The Simple Digital Arena''' for sponsorship reasons, is a football stadium in [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]], Scotland. It is the home of [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]]. The stadium is the sixth home of the club and replaced [[Love Street (stadium)|Love Street]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stmirren.info/id12.html |title=St Mirren Park |publisher=Stmirren.info |date=2009-01-31 |accessdate=2014-04-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.saintmirren.net/pages/?page_id=300 |title=St Mirren Football Club | Stadium History |publisher=Saintmirren.net |date= |accessdate=2014-04-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stmirren.info/id409.html |title=From St Mirren Park to St Mirren Park |publisher=Stmirren.info |date=2005-05-24 |accessdate=2014-04-14}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/st-mirren/3777960/Alex-Salmond-to-unveil-plaque-at-St-Mirrens-new-ground.html |title=Alex Salmond to unveil plaque at St Mirren's new ground |publisher= |work=Daily Telegraph |date=2008-12-15 |accessdate=2014-04-15}} ==History== [[File:St Mirren's new stadium - geograph.org.uk - 811248.jpg|thumb|left|225px|View of the stadium during construction]] Talks over a new stadium began on 15 January 2003, when the club met representatives from [[Aldi]] and [[Lidl]]. The club were looking to sell their ground at [[Love Street (stadium)|Love Street]] for retail development. Selling Love Street would secure the necessary funding to build the new stadium. Planning applications for a retail development at Love Street were passed on 24 May 2005 and the club subsequently sold the ground to [[Tesco]] on 25 April 2007 for £15 million. The new stadium site broke ground on 7 January 2008 and was officially opened on 31 January 2009 at a cost of £8 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.footballgroundguide.com/scotland/st_mirren.htm |title=Scottish Football Ground Guide: New St Mirren Park, St Mirren Football Club |publisher=Footballgroundguide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-03}} Before the first game at the new stadium there was a parade from Love Street to Greenhill Road to celebrate the opening of the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/73851-st-mirren-fans-final-march-from-love-street/ |title=St Mirren fans’ final march from Love Street | Football |publisher=STV |date=2009-02-03 |accessdate=2014-04-14}} Club chairman [[Stewart Gilmour]] and [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Alex Salmond]] were also present at the first match at the new ground. Alex Salmond unveiled a plaque before the game to commemorate the opening. The game between St Mirren and [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] finished in a 1–1 draw, with the first goal at the new stadium being scored by Kilmarnock striker [[Kevin Kyle]].{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Campbell |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=31 January 2009 |accessdate=22 October 2012 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/7858986.stm |title=St Mirren 1-1 Kilmarnock}} [[Dennis Wyness]] scored St Mirren's first goal at the new ground, in the same match. The opening match set the record attendance of 7,542, a record which still stands. St Mirren Park has also become the regular home of the [[Scotland national under-21 football team]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14457191.stm|title=St Mirren Park becomes home to Scotland's Under-21 side|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=9 August 2011|accessdate=9 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=2986&newsID=11384&newsCategoryID=1 |title=Scottish Football Association |publisher=Scottishfa.co.uk |date=2013-01-31 |accessdate=2014-04-15}} In November 2015, St Mirren agreed a two-year sponsorship deal with [[Renfrewshire Council]] to rename the stadium as the '''Paisley 2021 Stadium'''. This was to promote Paisley's bid to become a [[UK City of Culture]] in 2021.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34831026 |title=St Mirren Park in line for temporary name change in culture city bid |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=16 November 2015 |accessdate=17 November 2015}} In June 2018, the stadium was renamed as '''The Simple Digital Arena''' as part of a four-year deal with [[Glasgow]]-based IT firm Simple Digital Solutions.{{cite news |url=https://stv.tv/sport/football/1418644-st-mirren-rename-stadium-ahead-of-premiership-return/ |title=St Mirren rename stadium ahead of Premiership return |publisher=STV Sport |work= |date=2018-06-13 |accessdate=2018-06-13}} ==Construction== St Mirren Park is built on a 12.5 acre site on Greenhill Road in the [[Ferguslie Park]] area of the town. The previously unused site is less than a mile from the clubs former ground.{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumguide.com/stmirrenpark/ |title=St Mirren Park |publisher=The Stadium Guide |date= |accessdate=2014-04-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.romauk.net/newspages/stmirrenfootball.html |title=ROMA Publications Ltd, UK - Publishing, Advertising, Graphic Design |publisher=Romauk.net |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}} [[Barr Construction]] were responsible for the design and construction of the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.footballgroundguide.com/scotland/st_mirren.htm |title=Scottish Football Ground Guide: New St Mirren Park, St Mirren Football Club |publisher=Footballgroundguide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}} Their design consisted of four grandstands with a total capacity of {{SPFL-stadiums|mirren}}.{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/clubs/st-mirren/ |title=St Mirren Football Club|publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |accessdate=30 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumdb.com/stadiums/sco/st_mirren_park |title=St Mirren Park – |publisher=Stadiumdb.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}} The East Stand is the Main Stand. The North Stand is used by away fans. Larger away supports can also be seated in a section of the West Stand. The West Stand has the largest capacity of all the stands. Whilst the South Stand is the Family Stand.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.saintmirren.net/pages/?p=30285 |title=St Mirren Football Club | Match Day Info – St Mirren v Partick Thistle |publisher=Saintmirren.net |date=2014-01-24 |accessdate=2014-04-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumdb.com/stadiums/sco/st_mirren_park |title=St Mirren Park – |publisher=Stadiumdb.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-18}} *East Stand (Greenhill Road) - capacity 2,220. (Main Stand) *West Stand (Craigielea Drive) - capacity 2,516. (2 sections for Away Stand Overspill or small away support) *North Stand (Ferguslie Park Avenue) - capacity 1,633. (Away Stand) *South Stand (Drums Avenue) - capacity 1,654. (Family Stand) ==Facilities== On the outside of the stadium, promotional plaques have been constructed on the wall including fans names and loved ones. In the undercroft areas under each of the home support sections, large plaques dedicated to the members of the club's 'Hall of fame' have been erected by members of the supporters association and the website team, detailing player profiles and stats. Also, a 7-a-side pitch behind the North Stand is covered by the Airdome and can be hired by the public. ==Transport== [[Paisley St James railway station|Paisley St James Railway Station]], which is served by trains on the [[Inverclyde Line]] from [[Glasgow Central railway station|Glasgow Central]], is adjacent to St Mirren Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishgrounds.co.uk/st_mirren.htm |accessdate=22 October 2012 |title=St Mirren|work=Scottish Football Ground Guide|publisher=Duncan Adams|date=1 August 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118092001/http://www.scottishgrounds.co.uk/st_mirren.htm |archivedate=18 January 2012}} Since the stadium opened, some supporters campaigned for the local transport authorities to rename the station to ''Paisley St Mirren''. Following station improvements, the signage of the station was updated to read as "Paisley St James, alight here for St Mirren Park", as a compromise between supporter groups and the local transport regulators [[Strathclyde Partnership for Transport|SPT]]. [[Paisley Gilmour Street railway station|Paisley Gilmour Street]] is a 15-minute walk from St Mirren Park, but has a much more frequent service from Glasgow Central. The ground is very near to the [[M8 motorway (Scotland)|M8 Motorway]] and is accessed via junction 29. Fans travelling from [[North Ayrshire]] can also access the ground via the [[A737 road]]. There is a car park at the stadium for permit holders, and street parking is also available. ==See also== * [[History of Scottish football#Stadium moves and refurbishments|Scottish stadium moves]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|St. Mirren Park}} {{St Mirren F.C.}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} [[Category:Football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Renfrewshire]] [[Category:St Mirren F.C.]] [[Category:Scottish Premier League venues]] [[Category:Scottish Professional Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Scotland]]

Syracuse, NY 13210 | coordinates = {{Coord|43|0|52|N|76|06|59|W|type:landmark}} | opened = October 2000 | owner = [[Syracuse University]] | operator = Syracuse University | surface = ice {{convert|200|-|85|ft|m|abbr=on}} | tenants = [[Syracuse Orange]] ([[Syracuse Orange women's ice hockey|Women's ice hockey]]) ([[Division I (NCAA)|NCAA]])
Men's ice hockey ([[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]])
Synchronized skating | seating_capacity = 350 }} The '''Tennity Ice Skating Pavilion''' is an ice arena in [[Syracuse, New York]]. Named for donors Marilyn and Bill Tennity, the facility opened in October 2000 for the use of [[Syracuse University]] students.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} The facility is the home of Syracuse University's [[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]] Division I men's hockey team competing in the [[Eastern States Collegiate Hockey League]], and new [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] women's program playing in the [[College Hockey America]] conference.{{cite web|work=[[Syracuse University]]|url=http://skate.syr.edu/clubs.php|title=Clubs|accessdate=June 23, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205162234/http://skate.syr.edu/clubs.php|archivedate=February 5, 2011|df=}} The Ice Pavilion is also used for [[intramural]] hockey and [[broomball]] leagues, as well as Syracuse University physical education classes.{{cite web|work=[[Syracuse University]]|url=http://skate.syr.edu/programs.php|title=Programs|accessdate=June 23, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205162249/http://skate.syr.edu/programs.php|archivedate=February 5, 2011|df=}} The new women's hockey team locker room was designed by [[QPK Design]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} The facility features two ice sheets, a regulation [[NHL]] sized surface and a {{convert|94|-|85|ft|m|abbr=on}} oblong studio rink for [[ice skating]] and [[figure skating]]. ==See also== *[[Syracuse Orange]] *[[Syracuse Orange women's ice hockey]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *
